headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the PPG Industries Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Andrew, and I will be your conference specialist today. [Operator Instructions] Please note this event is being recorded. I would now
componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome to the PPG Industries Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Andrew, and I will be your conference specialist today. [Operator Instructions] Please note this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Scott Minder, Director, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. This is Scott Minder, Director of Investor Relations. We appreciate your interest in PPG Industries, and welcome you to this teleconference to review PPG's fourth quarter and full year 2015 financial results. Joining me on the call from
componenttext:
Good afternoon. This is Scott Minder, Director of Investor Relations. We appreciate your interest in PPG Industries, and welcome you to this teleconference to review PPG's fourth quarter and full year 2015 financial results. 
Joining me on the call from PPG are Michael McGarry, President and Chief Executive Officer; Frank Sklarsky, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Vince Morales, Vice President, Investor Relations and Treasurer.
Our comments relate to the financial information released on Thursday, January 21, 2016. I will remind everyone that we posted detailed commentary and accompanying presentation slides on the Investor Center of our website, ppg.com.
The slides are also available on the webcast site for this call and provide additional support to the opening comments Michael will make momentarily.
Following Michael's perspective on the company's results for the quarter and for the full year, a brief financial update from Frank, we will move to a Q&A session. Both the prepared commentary and discussion during this call may contain forward-looking statements reflecting the company's current view of future events and their potential effects on PPG's operating and financial performance.
These statements involve uncertainties and risks, which may cause actual results to differ.
The company is under no obligation to provide subsequent updates to these forward-looking statements.
This presentation also contains certain non-GAAP financial measures. The company has provided in the appendix of the presentation materials, which are available on our website, reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures.
For any additional information, please refer to PPG's filings with the SEC. 
Now let me introduce PPG President and CEO, Michael McGarry.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott, and good afternoon, everyone. Today, we reported fourth quarter and full year 2015 financial results. For the fourth quarter, our net sales were $3.7 billion, and our adjusted earnings per diluted share from continuing operations were $1
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott, and good afternoon, everyone. Today, we reported fourth quarter and full year 2015 financial results. For the fourth quarter, our net sales were $3.7 billion, and our adjusted earnings per diluted share from continuing operations were $1.23. While our net sales were flat with prior year, our sales in local currencies increased about 7% with higher sales volumes year-over-year and a continued benefit from acquisition-related sales. These sales increases were offset by persistent unfavorable foreign currency translation impacts. 
For the quarter, the unfavorable currency translation impact totaled about $250 million in sales and approximately $25 million on pretax income. Our sales volume growth in the quarter of nearly 2% represented our highest growth rate of the year. This solid volume growth stems from our validity to gain larger share of our customers' wallets through their adoption of new or leading PPG technologies. 
In addition, we benefited from broadening improvement in European demand as our volumes in this region steadily improved in each quarter of 2015. We grew coatings volumes 1% in Europe in the first quarter and steadily improved to 3% in the fourth quarter. 
We also returned to solid mid-single-digit percentage growth rate in Asia as demand in that region improved markedly in comparison with a weaker third quarter. Volume trends in the Americas were mixed with country but consistent with the prior year levels. We achieved organic growth in the U.S. and Mexico that was offset by lower year-over-year sales volumes in Canada and several South American countries. 
Our sales volume growth was broad based across our business portfolio led by Industrial Coatings segment, which grew by mid-single digits percentage and delivered sales volume gains in all our business units within the segment, including our general industrial business, where we reversed the negative sales volume trend we experienced in the second and third quarters. 
Also, the automotive OEM industry growth rate improved sequentially and year-over-year, and our automotive OEM coatings business continued to grow at a rate above the industry average. Rounding out the segment, our packaging coatings business continues to benefit from industry move to new interior can coatings. Customer adoption of our new interior can coating technology remains strong, supporting our mid-single-digit percentage growth in that business. 
In the Performance Coatings segment, automotive refinish, protective and marine coatings and architectural coatings EMEA grew sales volumes. Growth in architectural coatings in Mexico and the U.S. was offset by weaker demand in Canada, Brazil and China. Aerospace coating sales volume declined in relation to a strong growth in the prior year and due to year-over-year differences in certain customer order patterns. This was the first decline in aerospace volumes in quite some time, and we expect the business to return to growth in 2016. 
Finally, Glass segment sales volumes grew slightly principally due to higher flat Glass demand. Supplementing the company's volume growth in the quarter were acquisition-related sales gains of about 5%, stemming primarily from the Comex acquisition, which we completed in November 2014. 
For the fourth quarter, we generally experienced normal seasonal sales trends in all our businesses and regions. Lastly, overall selling prices were flat, which was consistent with our expectations communicated at the beginning of the year. 
From an earnings perspective, our fourth quarter adjusted earnings per share of $1.23 improved 17% versus the prior year. We accomplished this despite the unfavorable impact of foreign currency translation. 
We delivered higher year-over-year income in each reporting segment due to our improving sales volumes and an unwavering focus on cost, supplemented by earnings-accretive acquisitions. With respect to costs, in addition to achieving our acquisition-related cost synergies, we also realized initial benefits from our previously announced business restructuring. We will continue to recognize additional restructuring-related savings in 2016 as we implement these actions. 
In addition to cash deployment acquisitions, we also repurchased $250 million of PPG's stock in the fourth quarter. This brings our full share repurchase total to $750 million or about 7 million shares. In the quarter, our average diluted shares outstanding were 2.3% lower versus the previous year's fourth quarter. 
Now let me comment quickly on our full year results. On a full year basis, our sales were $15.3 billion, consistent with the prior year despite $1.1 billion of negative foreign currency headwinds. Our full year sales volumes grew about 1%, led by modest but broadening growth throughout the region or throughout the year in Europe. 
Our adjusted earnings per diluted share was a record $5.69, up 17% versus our prior record and consistent with the adjusted EPS growth rates we achieved each quarter this year. For the quarter and full year, we are pleased with our strong financial performance and overall operational execution, in which was a modest year from a global economic growth perspective. 
Over the year, we continue to execute on our strategic objectives. First and foremost was the successful integration of Comex acquisition. Now that we have lapped the acquisition's 1 year anniversary, let me say that Comex performance has been excellent on virtually every measure. Specifically, the business grew organically by high single-digit percentage in the first year of acquisition. We were successful during the year in capturing our targeted cost synergies. In addition, during 2015, we added revenue synergy targets and began to work toward achievement of those increased objectives. 
These additions include the sale of PPG legacy products through the Comex concessionaire network plus incremental sales synergies in Central America. Lastly, Comex has been maintained a pace of opening up a new concessionaire store location about every 2 days. They've added almost 190 locations in total for the year, and I'm proud to note that we recently reached a milestone of 4,000 store locations in Mexico. While this is a great accomplishment, we have still considerable organic growth opportunities ahead of us. 
In addition to the Comex results, we also completed 6 smaller acquisitions throughout 2015 with a purchase price of over $400 million. During the year, we continued our legacy of strong cash innovation with about $1.8 billion of cash generated from continuing operations. We also maintained our heritage returning cash to our shareholders, delivering about 60% of the cash generated for the year or about $1.1 billion through dividends and share repurchases. 
I will remind everyone that we have paid a dividend for 116 consecutive years and have raised our annual per share dividend payout for 44 consecutive years, including a 7% per share dividend increase in April 2015. Again, a very strong full year performance for our company. 
As we enter 2016, we anticipate global economic growth will continue but at a very paced and mixed by major economy. In the Asia-Pacific region, growth will most likely remain varied throughout the year but solid on a full year basis. Some of this 2016 year-over-year variation will be due to uneven 2015 regional volume patterns. 
A primary driver for growth in Asia is increased consumer spending, which is beneficial to PPG as this affects the majority of our products sold in the region. We ended the year on a strong note in Asia, and our order book for the first month of 2016 looks solid. 
Economic expansion in North America is likely to continue at a modest pace comparable to 2015 supported by multiple sectors. We anticipate continued improvement in construction markets in the U.S. and for Canada to stabilize a lower activity level realized in the second half of 2015. 
Overall, industrial activity is expected to remain modest but positive in comparison to the lower-than-anticipated 2015 level. We continue to expect solid organic growth in Mexico, supplemented by our revenue-related acquisition synergies. 
One item specific to PPG in 2016 is that we will continue with that multiyear U.S. architectural coatings branding initiatives. During 2016, we will be working with our major national retail or DIY customers on various modified branding initiatives. 
As a reminder, in 2015, we've rebranded our U.S. company-owned store network to PPG Paints. 
Moving to South America, where our business is relatively small at about 3% of total sales, demand in that region is expected to remain erratic and subdued. In Europe, we expect the economies to build on the broadening growth rate achieved in 2015, which would be beneficial to PPG as nearly 30% of our total sales are in that region. 
Favorable end-use market trends are expect to continue in 2016, particularly in automotive OEM coatings as industry builds growth rates in Europe and in aggregate, globally are expected to be positive for the year. Given that we have substantially reduced our cost structure in Europe, we expect incremental margins in that region to be in the 35% to 40% range. 
From an overall PPG perspective, we remain focused on delivering higher organic growth, including continued commercialization of our innovative industry-leading coatings technologies. Over the past several years, we have deployed many new or leading technologies for our end-use markets. These include our Compact Process technology in automotive OEM coatings, which has been widely adopted by customers as it reduces their facility construction costs and ongoing operating costs; our water-based automotive refinish coatings, which are now the leading water-based products in the industry. We've converted more auto body repair shops to waterborne coatings than the rest of the entire coatings industry combined. Our new interior can coatings realized growing consumer adoption over the past year. This allowed us to deliver mid-single-digit percentage growth, which is well above the packaging coatings industry growth rates with more to come in 2016. And several new products in our aerospace business and end-use market that is driven by new technologies that fit our technical strengths and capabilities. This is the primary reason why we have a leading position globally. 
In addition to organic growth, we will continue to be aggressive on cost and productivity initiatives as those of you who know us and followed us over the years, this is a never-ending quest for PPG. We are always looking for better ways to improve our cost structure. Finally, our balance sheet remains strong as we ended the year with cash and short-term investments of $1.5 billion. We intend to continue creating shareholder value through earnings-accretive cash deployment. We remain on pace with our prior commitment to deploy between $2 billion and $2.5 billion of cash in the years 2015 and 2016 combined, including the $1.15 billion we deployed in 2015. 
We expect coatings industry consolidation to continue in 2016. Our pipeline remains strong as we continue to bet potential acquisitions around the world. Share repurchases will also remain an integral part of our capital allocation strategy. Let me conclude by saying 2015 was an excellent year for PPG. We delivered 17% adjusted earnings per share growth despite stiff currency headwinds and an uneven regional economic growth. We are looking forward to another successful year in 2016. 
And now I'd like to turn it over to Frank to review a few 2016 financial assumptions.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael, and good afternoon, everyone. I'm going to cover several items that will assist in modeling PPG's 2016 sales and earnings. We have included in today's presentation materials a summary of these financial assumptions on Slide #12. Firs
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael, and good afternoon, everyone. I'm going to cover several items that will assist in modeling PPG's 2016 sales and earnings. We have included in today's presentation materials a summary of these financial assumptions on Slide #12. 
First is the carryover impact from the 6 acquisitions we completed throughout 2015. As we've discussed in the past, these acquisitions are expected to achieve full year sales of about $400 million in 2016. We realized about $150 million of sales in 2015 for these acquisitions and expect an incremental $250 million in 2016. This incremental revenue will be classified in the acquisition category until each acquired entity reaches its respective acquisition anniversary date, after which time, the entity's performance will be included in normal operating organic results. These acquisitions will typically achieve at or below the segment average margins as they become fully integrated into PPG. 
Next, we will continue to experience the impact of foreign currency translation headwinds as measured against the U.S. dollar. As a result, the company expects that year-over-year currency translation will unfavorably impact sales by $550 million to $600 million, and approximately 2/3 of this impact will be in the first half of the year. Pretax earnings will be impacted by about $70 million to $80 million with similar phasing for the year. These figures represent our current assumptions based on current exchange rates as of this week. Again, these impacts our currency translation related. Given the nature of our business, we typically do not incur significant transaction-related currency impacts. 
The next item relates to the company's pension and other postretirement benefits or OPEB expenses. Following an increase in 2015, we are expecting these expenses to decrease by about $20 million to $25 million in 2016. This decrease stems from our adoption of the split discount rate methodology for measurements of pension cost components, partly offset by slightly lower expected return on assets. 
We expect slightly higher interest costs in 2016, including the impact of our placements of long-term debt at the end of the first quarter 2015 along with changes in the cash balances. As a result, we expect a total of about $20 million of higher net interest expense year-over-year, and we provided our quarterly net interest estimates on the presentation slide. 
Next, we anticipate that the company's 2016 tax rates on ongoing earnings from continuing operations will be in the range of 24.5% to 25.5%. A comparable rate for 2015 was 24.5%. This increase relates primarily to our regional earnings mix. 
Finally, as Michael mentioned, the company still anticipates cash deployment of $2 billion to $2.5 billion for the years 2015 and 2016 combined for acquisitions and share repurchases. 
Once again, a summary of these financial assumptions is contained in the presentation materials provided for today's call. This now concludes our prepared remarks. Once again, we appreciate your interest in PPG. 
And now, operator, would you now please open the line for questions?

Are you seeing anything yet in your -- you indicated you're still engaged with a number of potential acquisition targets. Are you seeing any drop in the valuation multiples finally?

componenttextpreview: John, I think the way I would answer that is we don't see as much competition from the private equity side, but we have not seen any reduction in interest level from the strategics. So at this point in time, I think it's a little early. Now we'd be happy
componenttext: John, I think the way I would answer that is we don't see as much competition from the private equity side, but we have not seen any reduction in interest level from the strategics. So at this point in time, I think it's a little early. Now we'd be happy if it moved in that direction as you know. But right now, we'll just wait and see.

componenttext: Yes, John, consistent with what we've said previously, we saw modest benefits in 3Q and 4Q. We've not lapped those benefits yet. We've always said it takes 6 to 9 months for us to pull through any savings. And yes, before you ask, we expect our selling prices to be flat for 2016 similar to 2015. So we work with our suppliers on a regular basis. We expect to be -- price fairly, and we have a whole purchasing team out there that knows that's top of my mind.

componenttext: Michael, you've mentioned some rebranding through the DIY channel. Is that going to be both your major partners, and what are you going to do exactly there? And is there -- you mentioned you'd already rebranded the store base. Is there some savings that offsets that $15 million of incremental spend?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Bob, as you know, we started the rebranding of our stores in 2015. That was very successful. That work has been completed. So there's no carryover cost, if you will, for that. We do have agreement with our retail partners to begin some new rebrandin
componenttext: Well, Bob, as you know, we started the rebranding of our stores in 2015. That was very successful. That work has been completed. So there's no carryover cost, if you will, for that. We do have agreement with our retail partners to begin some new rebranding. I don't want to get into specifics because you have to wait until you see it on the shelves. So we also have some new wins for 2016 that will require replacing some product on the shelves. So all those costs are frontloaded into Q1 prior to the paint season, and so it's a onetime cost we wanted to make sure you were aware of.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I could follow up, I know you've talked about reinvigorating organic growth at the company following a lot of M&A work. Can you give us any updates on what you're doing or some specifics, maybe some anecdotes of successes and what's on the horizon?
componenttext: And if I could follow up, I know you've talked about reinvigorating organic growth at the company following a lot of M&A work. Can you give us any updates on what you're doing or some specifics, maybe some anecdotes of successes and what's on the horizon?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you started to see some of this. This is work that's been underway for quite some period of time. We have a lot of leading technologies that we were focused on, but maybe there's some additional regional opportunities for us in emerging regi
componenttext: Well, I think you started to see some of this. This is work that's been underway for quite some period of time. We have a lot of leading technologies that we were focused on, but maybe there's some additional regional opportunities for us in emerging regions. That's one. You've seen these significant adoption pickup rate in our packaging business. That's been a good one. You've seen in our refinished business more water-based sales there, and of course, in our automotive business, using the most recent acquisitions that we've done in REVOCOAT where those products are applied in the paint shop they had limited customers, a limited geographic scope, and we were going to take that out globally and get some shares there as well. So we've worked hard on trying to commercialize all this faster, and I think that's what the focus has been. We also had some new wins that we'll be rolling out later in 2016 as commercial transport. So that's all good as well. So altogether, I would say probably the most recent ones that you probably haven't seen in the past that are popping up would be our protective segment. In protective, we've had significant wins in dry docking, significant wins in the LNG sector, significant wins in some of what we call our advantage products, tank linings and things like that. So those are ones that we're rolling out globally as well. So I'd say that all positive.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from David Begleiter of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: The next question comes from David Begleiter of Deutsche Bank.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, in Performance Coatings, volumes fell 1% in 2015. I know you're expecting growth this year, but what would you expect volume growth to be in Performance Coatings in 2016?
componenttext: Mike, in Performance Coatings, volumes fell 1% in 2015. I know you're expecting growth this year, but what would you expect volume growth to be in Performance Coatings in 2016?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: In Performance Coatings? I would say that we should break that down into the various segments, right? So the aerospace, we would say that would be low single digits, so that is a reasonable number. If you look into PMC given our last quarter, I would say
componenttext: In Performance Coatings? I would say that we should break that down into the various segments, right? So the aerospace, we would say that would be low single digits, so that is a reasonable number. If you look into PMC given our last quarter, I would say that it should continue to be low single digits. Obviously, the marine side is a problem. The order book for the big guys in Korea, where 50% of what their expectations were so marine new-builds will continue to be a challenge, but the protective side should be really solid. If you look at our refinish business, miles driven continue to go up. Gas prices are down. Distracted driving is up. Insurance claims are up. So refinish has done quite well. So I would call that historically, that would be a 0 business, but I'd say it's going to be a low single-digit kind of year. And then that leaves architectural, and I think again that's going to vary considerably by the region. We were pleased. The U.K., Ireland, Benelux, Scandinavia, all had good 3-plus kind of numbers. That was good for us. France actually stabilized it. So we saw a couple of months in the fourth quarter that were marginally up. It's a little too early to tell yet what we expect there, but I would say France, I'm more optimistic now that I've been the last, say, 9 to 15 months. So that's all good. The Eastern European countries are -- they've had a lot of promotional challenges, but I would tell you overall, it should come back around. When you look at the U.S., we've obviously had some good growth in the U.S. except for the dealer market. The dealer market continues to be challenged. Canada, I think, is probably going to stabilize. So I don't expect a lot in there. Mexico, we've had tremendous growth there. We're going to continue to expect to grow 2x GDP. The one negative in Mexico is the fact that government spending has started to slow down with the price of oil dropping. I think Brazil's going to be a challenge. I think China is going to be a challenge. Australia should be good, at least mid- I would say low to mid-single digits in Australia. So that's a good market for us. So all in all, I would say we should be at or above GDP for the Performance Coatings segment.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: David, the one -- this is Vince. The one thing we do have is restructuring benefits. We announced a restructuring plan for everybody's recollection in April of 2015. We saw very modest benefits but targeted for all of '15, and we expect incremental benefits in 2016. That will be partially offset by changes in the corporate costs, which will get back to historical levels, but overall, our goal would be to gradually accrete the return on sales percentage overall for the company.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: The next question comes from Duffy Fischer of Barclays.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, just there's been a lot kind of talked about and written with the MROs in the refinished side of things and how they're rolling that out. As you look back at '15, how has that played out for you guys? And what would you look at going forwa
componenttext: First question, just there's been a lot kind of talked about and written with the MROs in the refinished side of things and how they're rolling that out. As you look back at '15, how has that played out for you guys? And what would you look at going forward, would there be a lot more that consolidation? And does that favor you, disfavor you? How would you think about that?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Duffy, this is Michael. I think you're referring to the MSOs, multi-shop operators. That trend line for a big guys that continue to buy the little guys is obviously positive for us. Some of these smaller shops lack the same productivity as the bigger shop
componenttext: Duffy, this is Michael. I think you're referring to the MSOs, multi-shop operators. That trend line for a big guys that continue to buy the little guys is obviously positive for us. Some of these smaller shops lack the same productivity as the bigger shops, too. That's where we bring a tremendous amount of value to our multi-shop operators. We're able to improve their business instead of getting 9 cars out of the shop, they can get 10 cars out in a day. So that's been a positive for us. So I'd tell you that our share in the U.S. continues to increase. I don't know how much more the MSOs will aggregate this year because when I think about it from a debt market, I'm not sure how aggressive they're going to be in trying to raise more debt given this environment. But regardless, we are totally supportive, and it has been a good trend for PPG.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: And then it's a little bit nitpicky, but it might be $20 million or so. Last year, currency hit you $250 million on revenue, $25 million on income, which was about a 10% margin. This year at the midpoint, you kind of moved that up to a 13% or 14% margin. What's the difference in how the currencies impacting earnings relative to sales this year versus last year?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Duffy, this is Frank. It really has to do with some of the mix of where the currency translation impacts are. So for instance, we have much larger component of Comex this year, and given the margin structures and given the relative proportion of that busi
componenttext: Duffy, this is Frank. It really has to do with some of the mix of where the currency translation impacts are. So for instance, we have much larger component of Comex this year, and given the margin structures and given the relative proportion of that business to the total PPG, that's really where the difference is. And so last year, the largest impact, for instance, was with the euro. It's a little bit more balanced instance of the currency impacts this year with a little bit maybe higher proportions of Latin America. So that would really be the difference.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: The next question comes from Rory Blake of Wells Fargo.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Frank Mitsch sitting in for Rory. Michael, in early September, we met with you, and you were talking about how you were concerned about 10% or just under 10% of the PPG portfolio mentioning Brazil, Russia heavy-duty equipment, et cetera. As we sit
componenttext: This is Frank Mitsch sitting in for Rory. Michael, in early September, we met with you, and you were talking about how you were concerned about 10% or just under 10% of the PPG portfolio mentioning Brazil, Russia heavy-duty equipment, et cetera. As we sit here today late or mid- to late January, what percent of the portfolio would you say you put in that concerning category?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, Frank, it probably hasn't changed too much. Russia, we still see that as a challenged market. Brazil is probably more challenged today than it used to be. Heavy-duty equipment, though, is I would say stabilized at a lower level, but it is d
componenttext: Well, I think, Frank, it probably hasn't changed too much. Russia, we still see that as a challenged market. Brazil is probably more challenged today than it used to be. Heavy-duty equipment, though, is I would say stabilized at a lower level, but it is down, but the negativeness of those numbers have significantly reduced. Besides that, I would tell you that the rest of our businesses are pretty good. So I don't know that I would change what you've got as a concern level.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very interesting. Obviously, you see the broader market melting not expecting that the global economy's going to tank here but based on the guidance that you put forth, it doesn't appear that, that is the case, and I'll take your response to reiter
componenttext: That's very interesting. Obviously, you see the broader market melting not expecting that the global economy's going to tank here but based on the guidance that you put forth, it doesn't appear that, that is the case, and I'll take your response to reiterate that that's terrific. If I could follow up and at same granularity to the productivity progress. I think you had talked about or PPG talked about us realizing about $70 million of benefits in 2016 and exiting that year at a run rate of $100 million. Is that still a target? Or is it higher, lower? How can you help us there?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's still about right. We said the program would get us between $15 million and $20 million by the end of 2015. That was accurate. Incremental $60 million to $70 million for 2016 bringing us a total of just under $100 million by the end of 2016 and the
componenttext: That's still about right. We said the program would get us between $15 million and $20 million by the end of 2015. That was accurate. Incremental $60 million to $70 million for 2016 bringing us a total of just under $100 million by the end of 2016 and then a little bit of trailing into '17, and those assumptions are still good. And we continue based on macroenvironment we're always looking for rationalization opportunities, and that will be a very strong focus for us.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Frank, you mentioned that corporate expenses are expected to tick higher in '16. Was that correct??
componenttext: Frank, you mentioned that corporate expenses are expected to tick higher in '16. Was that correct??

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say because of the fact that the Q4 number was a little bit more based on stock-based compensation cost, so probably revert back to something closer what we've seen historically in prior years as we get back into Q1 and for the remainder of the year.
componenttext: I'd say because of the fact that the Q4 number was a little bit more based on stock-based compensation cost, so probably revert back to something closer what we've seen historically in prior years as we get back into Q1 and for the remainder of the year.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. So it's based on stock-based compensation. That's the delta?
componenttext: All right. So it's based on stock-based compensation. That's the delta?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's one of the primary drivers really going down from the Q4 of the prior year, yes.
componenttext: That's one of the primary drivers really going down from the Q4 of the prior year, yes.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Jeff Zekauskas of JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question comes from Jeff Zekauskas of JPMorgan.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think your pension funding this year was about $300 million. What do you expect your pension funding to be next year?
componenttext: I think your pension funding this year was about $300 million. What do you expect your pension funding to be next year?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, the numbers will come down substantially. The number for this year really included that large $250 million that we put in the first quarter to really shore up the funding of the U.S. plans. Those numbers will come down into the I would say the kind
componenttext: Jeff, the numbers will come down substantially. The number for this year really included that large $250 million that we put in the first quarter to really shore up the funding of the U.S. plans. Those numbers will come down into the I would say the kind of the low double digits in terms of cash funding for 2016. We have very little of it in terms of mandatory funding for the year, so that was really related to some of the international plans but -- so that cash funding will not be what I would call material way. We may have some wind ups that we do in various parts of the world. Transparent about those when those happen but on that $250 million was probably an anomaly.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. In thinking about your overall volume growth for 2015, the geographic area that you had your difficulties in was North America that is, Europe and Asia grew 2% or 3%, and the U.S. and Canada was down 1%. Can you diagnose what went wrong in the U.S.
componenttext: Right. In thinking about your overall volume growth for 2015, the geographic area that you had your difficulties in was North America that is, Europe and Asia grew 2% or 3%, and the U.S. and Canada was down 1%. Can you diagnose what went wrong in the U.S. and Canada in 2015? And how you expect it to be different in 2016?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. Let's talk with Canada first. I mean, clearly the oil business has the most material impact on that, and that was a challenge for us. I would tell you that the slowing Canadian economy was also a challenge for us. When you shift into the U.S.,
componenttext: Yes, sure. Let's talk with Canada first. I mean, clearly the oil business has the most material impact on that, and that was a challenge for us. I would tell you that the slowing Canadian economy was also a challenge for us. When you shift into the U.S., clearly, we told you that the biggest challenge we had in the third quarter was the destocking that we saw due to the weather challenges we had in May and June. We have a very large stained business, if you will, in our architectural business, so that was one. Then you had heavy-duty equipment and industrial was a challenge. So those are all kind of negative. Also have a slowing in the industrial production. So when you factor that in and look at what we're looking at for 2016, I'm not nearly as pessimistic. I think industrial production will be more steady. You certainly see the housing market continuing to progress. I would tell you that our rebranding initiatives and our architectural business is a positive. The line reviews that we had with the major retail DIY chains were also positive. So I'm coming in the year feeling better about the U.S. So that would be my explanation.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from P. J. Juvekar of Citi.
componenttext: The next question comes from P. J. Juvekar of Citi.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Michael, I want to go back to some of your broader comments that you made. As you talked about broadening out of the recovery in Europe, it's something we hear a lot about. You talked about auto sales growing from sort of the mid-$17 million -- mid-1
componenttext: Yes. Michael, I want to go back to some of your broader comments that you made. As you talked about broadening out of the recovery in Europe, it's something we hear a lot about. You talked about auto sales growing from sort of the mid-$17 million -- mid-17 million unit level, do you think that's sustainable of given some cautious commentary from auto companies and auto parts companies so far?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, one of the leading indicators we look at it, of course, is registrations and the various countries. And if you look at registrations, they have been ahead of builds, and sales in the fourth quarter were substantially ahead builds. So inventory wise,
componenttext: Well, one of the leading indicators we look at it, of course, is registrations and the various countries. And if you look at registrations, they have been ahead of builds, and sales in the fourth quarter were substantially ahead builds. So inventory wise, even though Europe historically doesn't keep much inventory, we still think that's a positive. If you look in the southern countries in Europe, they all had very high growth rates albeit coming off an extremely low base, but that was our positive. So I'd say unlike in the U.S. where we are in the late innings in the U.S. for automotive, I'd say in Europe, we're more like the middle innings there. So I think we're -- that's just our viewpoint. Obviously, we could be wrong, P.J., but I think that's our take on it.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And my second question is on TiO2. Can you give us update on where does the Henan Billions plan stand on chlorite TiO2? And would you be willing to license that technology to other companies in China?
componenttext: And my second question is on TiO2. Can you give us update on where does the Henan Billions plan stand on chlorite TiO2? And would you be willing to license that technology to other companies in China?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, P.J., you probably saw our press release. We qualified the material, let's call it, in October. We had shipments on the water. We started commercially using the material in early December. More product is on the water going to other locations outside
componenttext: So, P.J., you probably saw our press release. We qualified the material, let's call it, in October. We had shipments on the water. We started commercially using the material in early December. More product is on the water going to other locations outside the U.S. So it's going to get qualified in Mexico. It's getting qualified in Europe. The bottom line is they are making good product. Their consistency is getting better, and we're pleased with what we're seeing. We have a most favored nations with them. So that's a positive for us as well. As far as licensing, no one else has approached us. But clearly, as we've demonstrated and people, I think, were a little bit concerned about, but we've demonstrated that we were able to support them with our technology, and it's running well, and the biggest thing we're working with them on now is consistency. And so far so good, and we're open. So if you know somebody we should be talking to, let us know. But right now, Henan Billions is our partner.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Arun Viswanathan of RBC.
componenttext: The next question comes from Arun Viswanathan of RBC.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, just had a question on the volume trends. It looks like Q4, you've got 2% growth and most of the '15 was about 1%, and just looking at the slide commentary, it looks like most of the commentary is for continued improvement in Q1 outside of season
componenttext: I guess, just had a question on the volume trends. It looks like Q4, you've got 2% growth and most of the '15 was about 1%, and just looking at the slide commentary, it looks like most of the commentary is for continued improvement in Q1 outside of seasonality. So I mean, would you characterize what you're seeing right now as any kind of positive inflation point and maybe you could talk about by end market especially automotive OEM and architectural?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so far in Q1, our order book looks very similar to what we saw early in Q4. As we told people in Q4, everybody thought the world was falling down in China. We tried to reassure people that we did not see that. I think people saw that car builds in C
componenttext: Well, so far in Q1, our order book looks very similar to what we saw early in Q4. As we told people in Q4, everybody thought the world was falling down in China. We tried to reassure people that we did not see that. I think people saw that car builds in China were up substantially in 4Q. We have good visibility all the way through Chinese New Year. So we see the Chinese auto builds continue to be up low single digits. Overall, we see the U.S. car market being up low single digits as well. But as we described in an earlier comment, we see that in the later innings of the ballgame. So those are our commentary. As far as the other markets, industrial has been an up-and-down market for us. We talked about heavy-duty equipment. The automotive parts business is being good. We have positive trends in coil in the fourth quarter. General finishes was up. Our electronic materials business was also up. That is not really due to the electronic materials growth as much as the new product introductions we have in electronic materials were pretty significant, and our customers are adopting these new technologies. So it's more like a win in the marketplace. I think I've covered architectural quite substantially. But if there's a market I missed, I'd be happy to cover it, Arun.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Arun, just adding to what Michael said, comments before too, we've seen some good wins in protective side. That should continue specialty coatings materials and packaging in that also applies to the packaging and industrial businesses in Europe, where we
componenttext: Arun, just adding to what Michael said, comments before too, we've seen some good wins in protective side. That should continue specialty coatings materials and packaging in that also applies to the packaging and industrial businesses in Europe, where we continue to see recovery and then see some nice wins there. So that's also going to add to the organic growth as we go forward.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Just as a follow-up. Have you seen any change in behavior amongst your customers? I mean, as you said a lot of us a lot of investors and observers are just kind of skittish in what's going on in the first half -- couple of weeks of the year. But ha
componenttext: Great. Just as a follow-up. Have you seen any change in behavior amongst your customers? I mean, as you said a lot of us a lot of investors and observers are just kind of skittish in what's going on in the first half -- couple of weeks of the year. But has there any change amongst your customers? And is that to be expected? Or are your business much longer cycle, and we should expect that.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we haven't got anybody calling us up all nervous. I would tell you the one packaging comment I dropped Frank didn't mention was that in California, with Proposition 65 concerns, we see more of our customers actually converting to the newer technolog
componenttext: Well, we haven't got anybody calling us up all nervous. I would tell you the one packaging comment I dropped Frank didn't mention was that in California, with Proposition 65 concerns, we see more of our customers actually converting to the newer technologies faster and sooner than we originally expected. So that's a positive for us. So I think we read more about the nervousness than we see about the nervousness. So maybe people would turn off their TVs, they might be little better.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Don Carson of Susquehanna Financial.
componenttext: The next question comes from Don Carson of Susquehanna Financial.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, I want to go back to architectural. Just both U.S. Canada and Mexico kind of North America outlook last year in the U.S. where obviously growth was below trend due to weather. Do you see that snapping back this year? Or do you see that being offs
componenttext: Michael, I want to go back to architectural. Just both U.S. Canada and Mexico kind of North America outlook last year in the U.S. where obviously growth was below trend due to weather. Do you see that snapping back this year? Or do you see that being offset by weakness in some of the energy related states? And more importantly, what was your growth in U.S. architectural last year versus the market? And how would you expect to compare to market this year? Then just any general comments on Canada and Mexico market growth outlook.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So, Don, let me start with the U.S. We saw the market at between 2% and 3%. That's been consistent. You've seen that with retailers as well. I would say that we were a tick below that. So from that standpoint, we were disappointed with our performan
componenttext: Okay. So, Don, let me start with the U.S. We saw the market at between 2% and 3%. That's been consistent. You've seen that with retailers as well. I would say that we were a tick below that. So from that standpoint, we were disappointed with our performance, but I would tell you that given what we've seen moving forward that, that will be a better year this year. We opened 25, essentially 25 new stores between U.S. and Canada. We opened 190 new store locations in Mexico. We've opened new locations in France as well. So I would say overall, our global store network will be bigger and better in 2016 than 2015. So that's kind of my summation of that, Don.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Don, we said earlier, I don't know if you caught it, this is Vince. We expected the Canadian market to remain soft in the first part of the year, but then we lapped that softness in the back half of the year, so that I think at a question on Canada as
componenttext: And Don, we said earlier, I don't know if you caught it, this is Vince. We expected the Canadian market to remain soft in the first part of the year, but then we lapped that softness in the back half of the year, so that I think at a question on Canada as well.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the protective side I guess, you also made a commentary about that protective, we're winning share both in the U.S. and Canada. So we have built into our plan continued growth in 2016.
componenttext: And on the protective side I guess, you also made a commentary about that protective, we're winning share both in the U.S. and Canada. So we have built into our plan continued growth in 2016.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just a follow-up on raws not so much coatings raws but hydrocarbon just, Vince, how much gas you consume your Glass business, and I would imagine just things like diesel fuel coming down given your truck fleet have to be a benefit as well. So wha
componenttext: And then just a follow-up on raws not so much coatings raws but hydrocarbon just, Vince, how much gas you consume your Glass business, and I would imagine just things like diesel fuel coming down given your truck fleet have to be a benefit as well. So what kind of hydrocarbon benefit do you see going into '16 versus '15?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Don, as you know, once we divested the commodity chemical business, our gas consumption dropped materially. A dollar change in natural gas for us is $15 million to $20 million a year on the cost side. We do have some customer price indexing that meet
componenttext: Yes, Don, as you know, once we divested the commodity chemical business, our gas consumption dropped materially. A dollar change in natural gas for us is $15 million to $20 million a year on the cost side. We do have some customer price indexing that meets that whether it be up or down. So it really gas price changes are not material impact for us in an individual quarter. We don't buy a lot of hydrocarbon materials for coating production. We do have the logistics costs. So diesel cost is important to us and our distribution businesses. We do see some benefit there as oil moves down, it takes a lot of pass-through we are seeing some inflation in salaries. So right now, those probably are moving in equal and opposite directions.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Mike Harrison of Seaport Global Securities.
componenttext: The next question comes from Mike Harrison of Seaport Global Securities.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, I was wondering if you could talk about competitive dynamics you're seeing in the auto refinish business. As you look to expand share, what does that mean in terms of what's going on with pricing?
componenttext: Michael, I was wondering if you could talk about competitive dynamics you're seeing in the auto refinish business. As you look to expand share, what does that mean in terms of what's going on with pricing?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the refinish business is a beautiful model from the standpoint that we have thousands and thousands and thousands of little customers, and what that means is that all -- we always have a price up opportunity this year, and about [ph] 2015, we had a
componenttext: Well, the refinish business is a beautiful model from the standpoint that we have thousands and thousands and thousands of little customers, and what that means is that all -- we always have a price up opportunity this year, and about [ph] 2015, we had a price increase in August. We would expect to have another price increase some time in the third quarter of 2016. This has been an industry trend for quite some period of time. I don't know that I could ever remember a time that refinish business hasn't had a price increase. So that's a positive, but it's not just PPG. I mean, that's an industry event as well.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: You got to remember too, pricing is only one element in terms of winning new business. PPG obviously for the color matching service capabilities think that we do really well technologies change and go more to waterborne and so on, that plays to PPG's adva
componenttext: You got to remember too, pricing is only one element in terms of winning new business. PPG obviously for the color matching service capabilities think that we do really well technologies change and go more to waterborne and so on, that plays to PPG's advantages.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, and then looking over to the packaging coatings side, you noted last quarter that you are going to be lapping the introduction of interior can coatings in that business, but it sounds like you saw strength despite what sounded like was going to
componenttext: All right, and then looking over to the packaging coatings side, you noted last quarter that you are going to be lapping the introduction of interior can coatings in that business, but it sounds like you saw strength despite what sounded like was going to be a challenging comp in that business. Could you talk about the uptake that you're seeing in the nonintense EPA coatings? How much additional runway does that have? And are you capturing any additional exterior coating business as a result of the interior product.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, this is Vince. We did see difficult comparable in Europe in the fourth quarter this year as they were prepping last year in the fourth quarter for the legislative change in France. So that was actually our lowest growth region this year due to the t
componenttext: Mike, this is Vince. We did see difficult comparable in Europe in the fourth quarter this year as they were prepping last year in the fourth quarter for the legislative change in France. So that was actually our lowest growth region this year due to the tough comp. It still grew year-over-year, but we had mid-single-digit or higher in the other regions as customers continue to roll this out around the world. So, and we still see very good runway. We're still in the infancy of this product introduction, and this has no impact on the outside of the can. So that's still being completed based on the similar metrics, similar customer metrics that was in the past.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Vincent Andrews of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: The next question comes from Vincent Andrews of Morgan Stanley.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question on pricing. You said for '15, you expected to be flat, looks like you're up 20 basis points. But if I'm remembering the trend through the year, seem to decelerate to bit in the second, third and fourth quarter, and you're anticipating bein
componenttext: Just a question on pricing. You said for '15, you expected to be flat, looks like you're up 20 basis points. But if I'm remembering the trend through the year, seem to decelerate to bit in the second, third and fourth quarter, and you're anticipating being flat again next year. So could you just give us a sense of maybe an end market basis or if you're having to pass through some cost just sort of what the dynamics are that sort of cause the deceleration through the year and how we should be thinking about the cadence in '16 as well.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: You described the situation accurately. Yes, we did have I'll call it less than 1% in Q1, and we ended the year just very modestly over 0, and we do reprice with new product introductions. We do have some customers, where we talk about pricing annually. A
componenttext: You described the situation accurately. Yes, we did have I'll call it less than 1% in Q1, and we ended the year just very modestly over 0, and we do reprice with new product introductions. We do have some customers, where we talk about pricing annually. And again, our situation as we look at it today is base case of flat price all in for the year. There are certain markets, where we do get price as Michael mentioned. There are other markets that are more competitive, but we're expecting flat price. We don't go into individual customers, individual businesses. That's been our customary pattern not to talk about this.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, okay. And then just a quick one on there was a comments on challenges in the independent dealer channel in the U.S. Could you just speak to those a little bit more and what you're doing to change that?
componenttext: Sure, okay. And then just a quick one on there was a comments on challenges in the independent dealer channel in the U.S. Could you just speak to those a little bit more and what you're doing to change that?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Vincent, this is Michael again. The independent dealer channel has been a declining channel for quite some period of time. These are small -- a lot of them are small business owners. As they retire, they would rather sell out to the large paint comp
componenttext: Sure, Vincent, this is Michael again. The independent dealer channel has been a declining channel for quite some period of time. These are small -- a lot of them are small business owners. As they retire, they would rather sell out to the large paint companies place. Plus as you know, home -- large retail partners continue to win share from that segment. So it is -- has been under pressure for a long time. We do not expect that trend to change, and so I think you can expect to see that going forward.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So there was nothing incrementally different about what you saw in the quarter versus the past?
componenttext: Okay. So there was nothing incrementally different about what you saw in the quarter versus the past?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, very similar, and the contraction rate remains minor but continuous.
componenttext: Yes, no, very similar, and the contraction rate remains minor but continuous.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Ghansham Panjabi of Baird.
componenttext: The next question comes from Ghansham Panjabi of Baird.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First off, on Comex. Michael, you gave us a nice update on integration. What about market conditions in Mexico and Central America as a whole? Has there been any sort of deviation in trend line there?
componenttext: First off, on Comex. Michael, you gave us a nice update on integration. What about market conditions in Mexico and Central America as a whole? Has there been any sort of deviation in trend line there?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We'll start with Mexico. The one slowing trend has been the government spending. The spending from the consumer has been very solid. We saw the gains all across our network whether it was in the north or the south. We added 190 stores. It was a very
componenttext: Yes. We'll start with Mexico. The one slowing trend has been the government spending. The spending from the consumer has been very solid. We saw the gains all across our network whether it was in the north or the south. We added 190 stores. It was a very good year for the Comex team, up high single digits for the year, so that was really a job well done by them. In Central America, we're in 7 small countries there. Those 7, all 7 had positive year-over-year growth. In 2 of them, we had particularly high-growth rates, but that was introduction of our new product down there, and that was specifically Panama and Costa Rica. We would expect to grow faster in those 2 particular countries than we would the others. The other should be at GDP kind of run rate. But overall, I would say both Mexico and Central America continue to be good markets for us overall.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on U.S. architectural and I'm sorry if I missed this, but can you give us a sense as to how the business performance in the big-box channel also retail stores, also any benefit from the warmer weather in the country during the fourth quarte
componenttext: Okay. And then on U.S. architectural and I'm sorry if I missed this, but can you give us a sense as to how the business performance in the big-box channel also retail stores, also any benefit from the warmer weather in the country during the fourth quarter, and also how would you characterize the pricing environment by channel at current?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we covered a lot of this originally, but the combined U.S., Canada stores network was slightly flat. It was obviously held back by Canada. So that was our challenge there. We've had positive growth with our DIY partners in the quarter. There
componenttext: Yes, I think we covered a lot of this originally, but the combined U.S., Canada stores network was slightly flat. It was obviously held back by Canada. So that was our challenge there. We've had positive growth with our DIY partners in the quarter. There was probably some material improvements to the weather but not as much as you would think because obviously, they're destocking at that period of time. So they probably took that opportunity to continue to move down, but all in all, we do think weather was a positive in the fourth quarter. And then we talked about the dealers just recently. So I think overall, we've been performing slightly under the market. If you say the market was 2% to 3%, we were one tick below that.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Nils Wallin of CLSA.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Nils Wallin of CLSA.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. First, would you remind us where you are in achieving all of the various Comex costs, revenue and Central America synergies?
componenttext: Yes. First, would you remind us where you are in achieving all of the various Comex costs, revenue and Central America synergies?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. This is Michael again. The cost synergies we laid out were $45 million to $50 million, and we are on our pace to beat that number. So that's good. On the sales synergies and the Mexican market, we said that number was going to be $40 million to
componenttext: Yes, sure. This is Michael again. The cost synergies we laid out were $45 million to $50 million, and we are on our pace to beat that number. So that's good. On the sales synergies and the Mexican market, we said that number was going to be $40 million to $50 million. Those are PPG products for the Comex legacy concessionaire network. We are solidly on pace to achieve those numbers, and then the Central America number was $60 million to $70 million, and based the most recent quarter I'm very comfortable with that number that we put out there. It's obviously early. We just closed on that acquisition in July, but the fourth quarter is the busy season down there, and we had a very good fourth quarter in the Central America market.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: Got it. And then just in terms of the cash deployment guidance, obviously, last quarter you've moved it up at the bottom end and then reiterated this quarter. I'm curious as to how you're thinking about next in '16, what would be the factors that would allow it or cause it to be the low what you've done in '15 or above what you've done in '15 and then what you think the mix will be? Is it likely to be more repurchases or more repurchases than M&A? Or is the mix likely to change?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Frank. So if you look at what we did in '15, we basically came in at half of what the midpoint of the range we reiterated. So 1.15 as compared with 2 to 2.5 for the 2-year period. And as always, the mix between share repurchase and acquisitions wi
componenttext: This is Frank. So if you look at what we did in '15, we basically came in at half of what the midpoint of the range we reiterated. So 1.15 as compared with 2 to 2.5 for the 2-year period. And as always, the mix between share repurchase and acquisitions will depend on what we have in the pipeline and the timing of any closing of any particular acquisition. We've continually said we have a really nice robust pipeline of things that we continue to look at around the various regions and the various businesses from an acquisitions standpoint, and that would be our preference to do accretive acquisitions. But as always, in any given quarter, that mix will change, and I think it's safe to assume that while we like to focus on the acquisitions, that share repurchases will continue to be an integral part of our capital deployment strategy and no reason to believe that will not continue including this quarter.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we will look at the whole landscape between what we have available acquisition pipeline and also in the deployment, and really it starts with what our cash from operations that we generate is going to be. And what we said is we came up with that ran
componenttext: Well, we will look at the whole landscape between what we have available acquisition pipeline and also in the deployment, and really it starts with what our cash from operations that we generate is going to be. And what we said is we came up with that range because we know how much cash we will have to deploy, and we fully intend to the midpoint of that range. And the only thing that will change the mix is the timing of the acquisition but the absolute dollars we intend to bring in are within that $2 billion to $2.5 billion range.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the weakness was really one part of it divided into 2 parts. One part of it was because in the fourth quarter 2014, we had a government entity double order whether they try to use up all budget or not, we're not able to predict, but we do know they d
componenttext: Yes, the weakness was really one part of it divided into 2 parts. One part of it was because in the fourth quarter 2014, we had a government entity double order whether they try to use up all budget or not, we're not able to predict, but we do know they double ordered and then the other half of the slowdown was due to our sealants business. We have a customer that has had a large new plane that they were working on, and they've gotten more consistent in ordering, and their work practices have gotten slightly better. So they're what I would call their waste has declined marginally. So now that that's more stable, we see them returning back to a year-over-year growth. The only thing about aerospace is the general and aviation market is very strong with big planes and slightly weak for little planes.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: There are no company-owned stores in Mexico. We have a dedicated concessionaire network. We do not ever plan to be in the company store business in Mexico. It is a combination of both our -- some of our long-term concessionaire partners as well as some ne
componenttext: There are no company-owned stores in Mexico. We have a dedicated concessionaire network. We do not ever plan to be in the company store business in Mexico. It is a combination of both our -- some of our long-term concessionaire partners as well as some new ones. So we have a lot of people that would like to have a store, and so we are very, very selective about finding those entrepreneurs that are going to live, eat, sleep, selling Comex paint and that's our desire is to make sure we find the right people, and it is a combination of both existing and new.

componenttext: Well, our goal is to bring working capital down percent of sales. You're correct over last 2 years brought down by about $300 million, about half of it was payables including financing programs and about half was inventory, where we took out about 5 days of operational inventory this year. We also improved the quality of the receivables by working down the percentage of pass-through. So we please with that, but we still have several days to go. We can get out of inventories and keep working on the past due receivables. So the goal of the continue bring down working capital by kind of on average 100 basis points a year for the next couple of years and then we think we'll be kind of in line with the group.
