componenttext: And if I could follow-up, I know you've talked about reinvigorating organic growth at the company following a lot of M&A work. Can you give us any updates on what you're doing or some specifics, maybe some anecdotes of successes and what's on the horizon?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you started to see some of this. This is work that's been underway for quite some period of time. We have a lot of leading technologies that we were focused on, but maybe there are some additional regional opportunities for us in emerging re
componenttext: Well, I think you started to see some of this. This is work that's been underway for quite some period of time. We have a lot of leading technologies that we were focused on, but maybe there are some additional regional opportunities for us in emerging regions. That's one. You've seen the significant adoption pickup rate in our packaging business. That's been a good one. You've seen in our refinished business more water-based sales there. And of course, in our automotive business, you've seen the most recent acquisitions that we've done in REVOCOAT, where those products were applied in the paint shop, they had limited customers, a limited geographic scope, and we are going to take that out globally and get some shares there as well. So we've worked hard on trying to commercialize all this faster, and I think that's what the focus has been. We also had some new wins that we'll be rolling out later in 2016 in commercial transport. So that's all good as well. So altogether, I would say probably the most recent ones that you probably haven't seen in the past that are popping up would be our protective segment. In protective, we've had significant wins in dry docking, significant wins in the LNG sector, significant wins in some of what we call our advantage products, tank linings, and things like that. So those are ones that we're rolling out globally as well. So I'd say all positive.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from David Begleiter of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: The next question comes from David Begleiter of Deutsche Bank.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, in Performance Coatings, volumes fell 1% in 2015. I know you're expecting growth this year. But what would you expect volume growth to be in Performance Coatings in 2016?
componenttext: Mike, in Performance Coatings, volumes fell 1% in 2015. I know you're expecting growth this year. But what would you expect volume growth to be in Performance Coatings in 2016?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: In Performance Coatings, I would say that we should break that down into the various segments, right? So the aerospace, we would say that would be low single digits. So that is a reasonable number. If you look into PMC given our last quarter, I would say
componenttext: In Performance Coatings, I would say that we should break that down into the various segments, right? So the aerospace, we would say that would be low single digits. So that is a reasonable number. If you look into PMC given our last quarter, I would say that it should continue to be low single digits. Obviously, the marine side is a problem. The order book for the big guys in Korea were 50% of what their expectations were. So marine new-builds will continue to be a challenge, but the protective side should be really solid. If you look at our refinish business, miles driven continue to go up. Gas prices are down. Distracted driving is up. Insurance claims are up. So refinish has done quite well. So I would call that -- historically, that would be a 0 business, but I'd say it's going to be a low single-digit kind of year. And then that leaves architectural, and I think, again, that's going to vary considerably by the region. We were pleased. The U.K., Ireland, Benelux, Scandinavia, all had good 3-plus kind of numbers. That was good for us. France actually stabilized. And so we saw a couple of months in the fourth quarter that were marginally up. It's a little too early to tell yet what we expect there, but I would say France, I'm more optimistic now that I've been the last, say, 9 to 15 months. So that's all good. The Eastern European countries are -- they've had a lot of promotional challenges, but I would tell you overall, it should come back around. When you look at the U.S., we've obviously had some good growth in the U.S. except for the dealer market. The dealer market continues to be challenged. Canada, I think, is probably going to stabilize. So I don't expect a lot in there. Mexico, we've had tremendous growth there. We're going to continue to expect to grow 2x GDP. The one negative in Mexico is the fact that government spending has started to slow down with the price of oil dropping. I think Brazil is going to be a challenge. I think China is going to be a challenge. Australia should be good, at least mid -- I would say low to mid-single digits in Australia. So that's a good market for us. So all in all, I would say we should be at or above GDP for the Performance Coatings segment.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very good, Mike. Same -- also in Performance Coatings, would you expect margins to be up in 2016 versus '15 given lower raws? And if so, would 50 basis points be a low bar from there?
componenttext: Very good, Mike. Same -- also in Performance Coatings, would you expect margins to be up in 2016 versus '15 given lower raws? And if so, would 50 basis points be a low bar from there?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, I think it's a little early to answer that question. In my opening commentary, you saw that we said pricing would be flat. We expect to continue to see modest raw material deflation. So I think putting a number on it is way too early.
componenttext: David, I think it's a little early to answer that question. In my opening commentary, you saw that we said pricing would be flat. We expect to continue to see modest raw material deflation. So I think putting a number on it is way too early.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, the one -- this is Vince. The one thing we do have is restructuring benefits. We announced a restructuring plan for everybody's recollection in April of 2015. We saw very modest benefits but targeted for all of '15, and we expect incremental benefi
componenttext: David, the one -- this is Vince. The one thing we do have is restructuring benefits. We announced a restructuring plan for everybody's recollection in April of 2015. We saw very modest benefits but targeted for all of '15, and we expect incremental benefits in 2016. That will be partially offset by changes in the corporate cost, which should get back to historical levels. But overall, our goal would be to gradually accrete the return on sales percentage overall for the company.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Duffy Fischer of Barclays.
componenttext: The next question comes from Duffy Fischer of Barclays.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, just there's been a lot kind of talked about and written with the MROs in the refinished side of things and how they are rolling that up. As you look back at '15, how has that played out for you guys and what would you look at going forwar
componenttext: First question, just there's been a lot kind of talked about and written with the MROs in the refinished side of things and how they are rolling that up. As you look back at '15, how has that played out for you guys and what would you look at going forward? Will there be a lot more of that consolidation? And does that favor you or disfavor you? How would you think about that?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Duffy, this is Michael. I think you're referring to the MSOs, multi-shop operators. That trend line for the big guys that continue to buy the little guys is obviously a positive for us. Some of these smaller shops lack the same productivity as the bigger
componenttext: Duffy, this is Michael. I think you're referring to the MSOs, multi-shop operators. That trend line for the big guys that continue to buy the little guys is obviously a positive for us. Some of these smaller shops lack the same productivity as the bigger shops, too. That's where we bring tremendous amount of value to our multi-shop operators. We're able to improve their business. Instead of getting 9 cars out of the shop, they can get 10 cars out in a day. So that's been a positive for us. So I'd tell you that our share in the U.S. continues to increase. I don't know how much more the MSOs will aggregate this year because when I think about it from a debt market, I'm not sure how aggressive they're going to be in trying to raise more debt given this environment. But regardless, we are totally supportive, and it has been a good trend for PPG.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then it's a little bit nitpicky, but it might be $20 million or so. Last year, currency hit you $250 million on revenue, $25 million on income, which was about a 10% margin. This year at the midpoint, you've kind of moved that up to a 13% or 14% margi
componenttext: And then it's a little bit nitpicky, but it might be $20 million or so. Last year, currency hit you $250 million on revenue, $25 million on income, which was about a 10% margin. This year at the midpoint, you've kind of moved that up to a 13% or 14% margin. What's the difference in how the currency is impacting earnings relative to sales this year versus last year?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Duffy, this is Frank. It really has to do with some of the mix of where the currency translation impacts are. So for instance, so we have much larger component of Comex this year. And given the margin structures and given that relative proportion of that
componenttext: Duffy, this is Frank. It really has to do with some of the mix of where the currency translation impacts are. So for instance, so we have much larger component of Comex this year. And given the margin structures and given that relative proportion of that business to the total PPG, that's really where the difference is. And so last year, the largest impact, for instance, was the euro. It's a little bit more balanced in terms of the currency impacts this year with a little bit maybe more higher proportion of Latin America. So that would really be the difference.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Rory Blake of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: The next question comes from Rory Blake of Wells Fargo.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Frank Mitsch sitting in for Rory. Michael, in early September, we met with you, and you were talking about how you were concerned about 10% or just under 10% of the PPG portfolio mentioning Brazil, Russia, heavy-duty equipment, et cetera. As we si
componenttext: This is Frank Mitsch sitting in for Rory. Michael, in early September, we met with you, and you were talking about how you were concerned about 10% or just under 10% of the PPG portfolio mentioning Brazil, Russia, heavy-duty equipment, et cetera. As we sit here today late -- or mid- to late January, what percent of the portfolio would you say you've put in that concerning category?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, Frank, it probably hasn't changed too much. Russia, we still see that as a challenged market. Brazil is probably more challenged today than it used to be. Heavy-duty equipment, though, is I would say stabilized at a lower level, but it is d
componenttext: Well, I think, Frank, it probably hasn't changed too much. Russia, we still see that as a challenged market. Brazil is probably more challenged today than it used to be. Heavy-duty equipment, though, is I would say stabilized at a lower level, but it is down, but the negativeness of those numbers have significantly reduced. Besides that, I would tell you that the rest of our businesses are pretty good. So I don't know that I would change what you got as a concern level.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very interesting. Obviously, you see the broader market melting, expecting that the global economy is going to tank here. But based on the guidance that you've put forth, it doesn't appear that, that is the case. And I'll take your response to reit
componenttext: That's very interesting. Obviously, you see the broader market melting, expecting that the global economy is going to tank here. But based on the guidance that you've put forth, it doesn't appear that, that is the case. And I'll take your response to reiterate that. That's terrific. If I could follow-up and add some granularity to the productivity progress, I think you had talked about -- or PPG talked about us realizing about $70 million of benefits in 2016 and exiting the year at a run rate of $100 million. Is that still the target? Or is it higher or lower? How can you help us there?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Frank, that's still about right. Now, we said that the program would get us between $15 million and $20 million accumulated by the end of 2015, and that was accurate. And the incremental $60 million to $70 million for 2016 bringing us a total of just u
componenttext: So Frank, that's still about right. Now, we said that the program would get us between $15 million and $20 million accumulated by the end of 2015, and that was accurate. And the incremental $60 million to $70 million for 2016 bringing us a total of just under $100 million by the end of 2016 and then a little bit of trailing into '17, and those assumptions are still good. And nevertheless we continue, based on the macroenvironment, we're always looking for additional rationalization opportunities, and that will be a very strong focus for us.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: But Frank, you mentioned, though, that corporate expenses are expected to tick higher in '16. Was that correct?
componenttext: But Frank, you mentioned, though, that corporate expenses are expected to tick higher in '16. Was that correct?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say that because of the fact that the Q4 number was a little bit more based on stock-based compensation cost, it'll probably revert back to something closer what we've seen historically in prior years as we get back into Q1 and for the remainder of th
componenttext: I'd say that because of the fact that the Q4 number was a little bit more based on stock-based compensation cost, it'll probably revert back to something closer what we've seen historically in prior years as we get back into Q1 and for the remainder of the year.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. So it's based on the stock-based compensation, that's the delta?
componenttext: All right. So it's based on the stock-based compensation, that's the delta?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That was one of the primary drivers really going down from the Q4 of the prior year, yes.
componenttext: That was one of the primary drivers really going down from the Q4 of the prior year, yes.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Jeff Zekauskas of JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question comes from Jeff Zekauskas of JPMorgan.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think your pension funding this year was about $300 million. What do you expect your pension funding to be next year?
componenttext: I think your pension funding this year was about $300 million. What do you expect your pension funding to be next year?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the numbers will come down substantially. The number for this year, really, they included that large $250 million that we put in the first quarter to really shore up the funding of the U.S. plans. Those numbers will come down into the -- I would say
componenttext: Yes, the numbers will come down substantially. The number for this year, really, they included that large $250 million that we put in the first quarter to really shore up the funding of the U.S. plans. Those numbers will come down into the -- I would say the kind of a low double digits in terms of cash funding for 2016. We have very little of it in terms of mandatory funding for the year, so -- and that was really related to some of the international plans, but -- so that cash funding will not be what I always call kind of a material way. We may have some windups that we do in various parts of the world, and we'll be very transparent about those when those happen. But on a trend basis, that $250 million was probably an anomaly.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Your -- when thinking about your overall volume growth for 2015, the geographic area that you had your difficulties in was North America. That is, Europe and Asia grew 2% or 3%, and the U.S. and Canada was down 1%. Can you diagnose what went wrong
componenttext: Right. Your -- when thinking about your overall volume growth for 2015, the geographic area that you had your difficulties in was North America. That is, Europe and Asia grew 2% or 3%, and the U.S. and Canada was down 1%. Can you diagnose what went wrong in the U.S. and Canada in 2015? And how you expect it to be different in 2016?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. Let's talk with Canada first. I mean, clearly the oil business had the first material impact on that, and that was a challenge for us. I would tell you that the slowing Canadian economy was also a challenge for us. When you shift into the U.S.,
componenttext: Yes, sure. Let's talk with Canada first. I mean, clearly the oil business had the first material impact on that, and that was a challenge for us. I would tell you that the slowing Canadian economy was also a challenge for us. When you shift into the U.S., clearly, we told you that the biggest challenge we had in the third quarter was the destocking that we saw due to the weather challenges we had in May and June. We have a very large stain business, if you will, in our architectural business, so that was one. Then you had heavy-duty equipment and industrial was a challenge. So those were all kind of the negative. We also had a slowing in the industrial production. So when you factor that in and look at what we're looking at for 2016, I'm not nearly as pessimistic. I think industrial production will be more steady. You certainly see the housing market continuing to progress. I would tell you that our rebranding initiatives in our architectural business is a positive. The line reviews that we had with the major retail DIY chains were also positive. So I'm coming in the year feeling better about the U.S. So that would be my explanation.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from P.J. Juvekar of Citi.
componenttext: The next question comes from P.J. Juvekar of Citi.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Michael, I want to go back to some of your broader comments that you made. You talked about broadening out of the recovery in Europe, which is not something we have heard a lot about. You talked about auto sales growing from sort of the mid-$17 milli
componenttext: Yes. Michael, I want to go back to some of your broader comments that you made. You talked about broadening out of the recovery in Europe, which is not something we have heard a lot about. You talked about auto sales growing from sort of the mid-$17 million -- or mid-17 million unit level. Do you think that's sustainable given some cautious commentary from auto companies and auto parts companies so far?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, one of the leading indicators we look at, of course, is registrations and the various countries. And if you look at registrations, they have been ahead of builds, and sales in the fourth quarter were substantially ahead of builds. So inventory-wise,
componenttext: Well, one of the leading indicators we look at, of course, is registrations and the various countries. And if you look at registrations, they have been ahead of builds, and sales in the fourth quarter were substantially ahead of builds. So inventory-wise, even though Europe historically doesn't keep much inventory, we still think that's a positive. If you look in the southern countries in Europe, they all had very high growth rates albeit coming off an extremely low base, but those are positives. So I'd say unlike in the U.S. where we're in the late innings in the U.S. for automotive, I'd say in Europe, we're more like the middle innings there. So I think we're -- that's just our viewpoint. Obviously, we could be wrong, P.J., but I think that's our take on it.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And my second question is on TiO2. Can you just give us update on where does the Henan Billions plan stand on chloride TiO2? And would you be willing to license that technology to other companies in China?
componenttext: And my second question is on TiO2. Can you just give us update on where does the Henan Billions plan stand on chloride TiO2? And would you be willing to license that technology to other companies in China?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, P.J., you probably saw our press release. We qualified the material, let's call it, in October. We had shipments on the water. We started commercially using the material in early December. More product is on the water going to other locations outside
componenttext: So, P.J., you probably saw our press release. We qualified the material, let's call it, in October. We had shipments on the water. We started commercially using the material in early December. More product is on the water going to other locations outside the U.S. So it's going to get qualified in Mexico. It's getting qualified in Europe. The bottom line is they are making good products. Their consistency is getting better, and we're pleased with what we're seeing. We have our most-favored nations with them. So that's a positive for us as well. As far as licensing, no one else has approached us. But clearly, as we've demonstrated and people, I think, were a little bit concerned about, but we've demonstrated that we were able to support them with our technology, and it's running well. And the biggest thing we're working with them on now is consistency. And so far so good, and we're open. So if you know somebody we should be talking to, let us know. But right now, Henan Billions is our partner.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Arun Viswanathan of RBC.
componenttext: The next question comes from Arun Viswanathan of RBC.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, just had a question on the volume trends. It looks like Q4, you've got 2% growth and most of '15 was about 1%. And then -- and just looking at the slide commentary, it looks like most of the commentary is for continued improvement in Q1 outside o
componenttext: I guess, just had a question on the volume trends. It looks like Q4, you've got 2% growth and most of '15 was about 1%. And then -- and just looking at the slide commentary, it looks like most of the commentary is for continued improvement in Q1 outside of seasonality. So I mean, would you characterize what you're seeing right now as any kind of positive inflection point, and maybe you can talk about by end market especially automotive OEM and architectural?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so far, in Q1, our order book looks very similar to what we saw early in Q4. As you -- as we told people in Q4, everybody thought the world was falling down in China. We tried to reassure people that we did not see that. I think people saw that car
componenttext: Well, so far, in Q1, our order book looks very similar to what we saw early in Q4. As you -- as we told people in Q4, everybody thought the world was falling down in China. We tried to reassure people that we did not see that. I think people saw that car builds in China were up substantially in 4Q. We have good visibility all the way through Chinese New Year. So we see the Chinese auto builds continue to be up low single digits. Overall, we see the U.S. car market being up low single digits as well. But as we described in an earlier comment, we see that in the later innings of the ball game. So those are our commentary. As far as the other markets, industrial has been an up-and-down market for us. We talked about heavy-duty equipment. The automotive parts business has been good. We had positive trends in coil in the fourth quarter. General finishes was up. Our electronic materials business was also up. That is not really due to the electronic materials growth as much as the new product introductions we have in electronic materials were pretty significant, and our customers are adopting these new technologies. So it's more like a win in the marketplace. I think I've covered architectural quite substantially, but if there's a market I missed, I'd be happy to cover it, Arun.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, that's fair enough.
componenttext: No, that's fair enough.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Arun, just adding to what Michael said, referring to his comments before, too, we've seen some good wins on the protective side. That should continue, specialty coatings materials and packaging. That also applies to the packaging and industrial businesses
componenttext: Arun, just adding to what Michael said, referring to his comments before, too, we've seen some good wins on the protective side. That should continue, specialty coatings materials and packaging. That also applies to the packaging and industrial businesses in Europe, where we continue to see recovery and then see some nice wins there. So that's also going to add to the organic growth as we go forward.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just as a follow-up, I mean, have you seen any change in behavior amongst your customers? I mean, as you said, a lot of us, a lot of investors and then observers are just kind of skittish in what's going on in the first half -- couple of weeks
componenttext: Great. And just as a follow-up, I mean, have you seen any change in behavior amongst your customers? I mean, as you said, a lot of us, a lot of investors and then observers are just kind of skittish in what's going on in the first half -- couple of weeks of the year. But has there been any change amongst your customers and is that to be expected? Or are your businesses much longer cycle and we should expect that?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we haven't gotten anybody calling us up all nervous. I would tell you, the one packaging comment I'd throw out there that Frank didn't mention was that in California, with Proposition 65 concerns, we see more of our customers actually converting to
componenttext: Well, we haven't gotten anybody calling us up all nervous. I would tell you, the one packaging comment I'd throw out there that Frank didn't mention was that in California, with Proposition 65 concerns, we see more of our customers actually converting to the newer technologies faster and sooner than we originally expected. So that's a positive for us. So I think we read more about the nervousness than we see about the nervousness. So maybe if people would turn off their TVs, they might feel a little better.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Don Carson of Susquehanna Financial.
componenttext: The next question comes from Don Carson of Susquehanna Financial.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, I want to go back to architectural. Just both U.S., Canada and Mexico, kind of the North America outlook. Last year in the U.S., where obviously growth was below trend due to weather, do you see that snapping back this year? Or do you see that be
componenttext: Michael, I want to go back to architectural. Just both U.S., Canada and Mexico, kind of the North America outlook. Last year in the U.S., where obviously growth was below trend due to weather, do you see that snapping back this year? Or do you see that being offset by weakness in some of the energy-related states? And more importantly, what was your growth in U.S. architectural last year versus the market? And how would you expect it to compare to market this year? And then just any general comments on Canada and Mexico market growth outlook.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So, Don, let me start with the U.S. We saw the market at between 2% and 3%. That's been consistent. You've seen that with retailers as well. I would say that we were a tick below that. So from that standpoint, we were disappointed with our performan
componenttext: Okay. So, Don, let me start with the U.S. We saw the market at between 2% and 3%. That's been consistent. You've seen that with retailers as well. I would say that we were a tick below that. So from that standpoint, we were disappointed with our performance. But I would tell you that given what we've seen moving forward that, that will be a better year this year. We opened 25 -- essentially 25 new stores between U.S. and Canada. We opened 190 new store locations in Mexico. We've opened new locations in France as well. So I would say, overall, our global store network will be bigger and better in 2016 than in 2015. So that's kind of my summation of that, Don.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Don, we said earlier -- I don't know if you caught it, this is Vince, that we expected the Canadian market to remain soft in the first part of the year, but then we've lapped that softness in the back half of the year, so that -- I think you had a que
componenttext: And Don, we said earlier -- I don't know if you caught it, this is Vince, that we expected the Canadian market to remain soft in the first part of the year, but then we've lapped that softness in the back half of the year, so that -- I think you had a question on Canada as well.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the protective side, I guess, you also made a commentary about that. Protective [indiscernible] market, we're winning share both in the U.S. and Canada. So we have built into our plan continued growth in 2016.
componenttext: And on the protective side, I guess, you also made a commentary about that. Protective [indiscernible] market, we're winning share both in the U.S. and Canada. So we have built into our plan continued growth in 2016.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just a follow-up on raws, not so much coatings raws but just hydrocarbon. Just, Vince, can you remind me how much gas you consume in your glass business. And I would imagine just things like diesel fuel coming down given how substantial your truc
componenttext: And then just a follow-up on raws, not so much coatings raws but just hydrocarbon. Just, Vince, can you remind me how much gas you consume in your glass business. And I would imagine just things like diesel fuel coming down given how substantial your truck fleet are have to be a benefit as well. So what kind of hydrocarbon benefit do you see going into '16 versus '15?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Don, as you know, once we divested the commodity chemical business, our gas consumption dropped materially. A dollar change in natural gas for us is $15 million to $20 million a year. On the cost side, we do have some customer price indexing that mut
componenttext: Yes, Don, as you know, once we divested the commodity chemical business, our gas consumption dropped materially. A dollar change in natural gas for us is $15 million to $20 million a year. On the cost side, we do have some customer price indexing that mutes that whether it be up or down. So really, gas price changes are not material impact for us in any individual quarter. We don't buy a lot of hydrocarbon materials for coatings production. We do have logistics costs, so diesel cost is important to us in our distribution businesses. We do see some benefit there as oil moves down. It takes a while to pass-through. We are seeing some inflation in trucker salaries. So right now, those probably are moving in equal and opposite directions.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Mike Harrison of Seaport Global Securities.
componenttext: The next question comes from Mike Harrison of Seaport Global Securities.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, I was wondering if you could talk about competitive dynamics you're seeing in the auto refinish business. As you look to expand share, what does that mean in terms of what's going on with pricing?
componenttext: Michael, I was wondering if you could talk about competitive dynamics you're seeing in the auto refinish business. As you look to expand share, what does that mean in terms of what's going on with pricing?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the refinish business is a beautiful model from the standpoint that we have thousands and thousands and thousands of little customers. And what that means is that all -- we always have a price-up opportunity this year. And as well in 2015, we had a
componenttext: Well, the refinish business is a beautiful model from the standpoint that we have thousands and thousands and thousands of little customers. And what that means is that all -- we always have a price-up opportunity this year. And as well in 2015, we had a price increase in August. We would expect to have another price increase sometime in the third quarter of 2016. This has been an industry trend for quite some period of time. I don't know that I can ever remember a time that refinish business hasn't had a price increase. So that's a positive. But it's not just PPG, I mean, that's an industry event as well.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And really remember, too, that pricing is just only one element in terms of winning on new business as PPG is known obviously for the color matching and the service capabilities, the things that we do really well. And as the technologies change and go mor
componenttext: And really remember, too, that pricing is just only one element in terms of winning on new business as PPG is known obviously for the color matching and the service capabilities, the things that we do really well. And as the technologies change and go more to waterborne and so on, that plays to PPG's advantages.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then looking over to the packaging coatings side, you noted last quarter that you were going to be lapping the introduction of interior can coatings in that business. But it sounds like you saw strength despite what sounded like what's goin
componenttext: All right. And then looking over to the packaging coatings side, you noted last quarter that you were going to be lapping the introduction of interior can coatings in that business. But it sounds like you saw strength despite what sounded like what's going to be a challenging comp in that business. Can you talk about the uptick that you're seeing in the non-intent BPA coatings? How much additional runway does that have? And are you capturing any additional exterior coating business as a result of the interior product?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, this is Vince. We did see difficult comparable in Europe in the fourth quarter this year as they were prepping last year in the fourth quarter for the legislative change in France. So that was actually our lowest growth region this year due to the t
componenttext: Mike, this is Vince. We did see difficult comparable in Europe in the fourth quarter this year as they were prepping last year in the fourth quarter for the legislative change in France. So that was actually our lowest growth region this year due to the tough comp. It still grew year-over-year, but we had mid-single-digit or higher in the other regions as customers continue to roll this out around the world. So -- and we still see a very good runway. We're still in the infancy of this product introduction, and this has no impact on the outside of the can. So that's still being competed based on the similar metrics it was in the past -- similar customer metrics it was in the past.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Vincent Andrews of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: The next question comes from Vincent Andrews of Morgan Stanley.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question on pricing. You said for '15, you expect it to be flat, looks like you're up 20 basis points. But if I'm remembering the trend through the year, it seemed to decelerate a bit in the second, third and fourth quarter, and you're anticipating
componenttext: Just a question on pricing. You said for '15, you expect it to be flat, looks like you're up 20 basis points. But if I'm remembering the trend through the year, it seemed to decelerate a bit in the second, third and fourth quarter, and you're anticipating being flat again next year. So could you just give us a sense of maybe on an end market basis or if you're having to pass-through some costs? Just sort of what the dynamics are that sort of caused the deceleration through the year and then how we should be thinking about the cadence in '16 as well?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Vincent. And if you look at -- you described the situation accurately. Yes, we did have, I'll call it, less than 1% in Q1, and we ended the year at just very modestly over 0. We do reprice with new product introductions. We do have some customers, wh
componenttext: Yes, Vincent. And if you look at -- you described the situation accurately. Yes, we did have, I'll call it, less than 1% in Q1, and we ended the year at just very modestly over 0. We do reprice with new product introductions. We do have some customers, where we talk about price annually. And our -- again, our situation as we look at it today is base case of flat price all-in for the year. There are certain markets where we do get price as Michael mentioned. There are other markets that are more competitive, but we're expecting flat price. We don't go into individual customers, individual businesses. That's been our customary pattern not to talk about those.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, okay. And then just a quick one on -- there was a comment on challenges in the independent dealer channel in the U.S. Could you just speak to those a little bit more and what you're doing to change that?
componenttext: Sure, okay. And then just a quick one on -- there was a comment on challenges in the independent dealer channel in the U.S. Could you just speak to those a little bit more and what you're doing to change that?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Vincent. This is Michael, again. The independent dealers channel has been a declining channel for quite some period of time. These are small -- a lot of them are small business owners. As they retire, they would rather sell out to the large paint co
componenttext: Sure, Vincent. This is Michael, again. The independent dealers channel has been a declining channel for quite some period of time. These are small -- a lot of them are small business owners. As they retire, they would rather sell out to the large paint companies. Plus as you know, home -- large retail partners continue to win share from that segment. So it is -- has been under pressure for a long time. We do not expect that trend to change, and so I think you can expect to see that going forward.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So there was nothing incrementally different about what you saw in the quarter versus the past?
componenttext: Okay. So there was nothing incrementally different about what you saw in the quarter versus the past?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, very similar. And the contraction rate remains minor but continuous.
componenttext: Yes, very similar. And the contraction rate remains minor but continuous.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Ghansham Panjabi of Baird.
componenttext: The next question comes from Ghansham Panjabi of Baird.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First off, on Comex, Michael, you gave us a nice update on integration. What about market conditions in Mexico and Central America as a whole? Has there been any sort of deviation in the trend line there?
componenttext: First off, on Comex, Michael, you gave us a nice update on integration. What about market conditions in Mexico and Central America as a whole? Has there been any sort of deviation in the trend line there?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We'll start with Mexico. The one slowing trend has been the government spending. The spending from the consumer has been very solid. We saw good gains all across our network whether it was in the north or the south. We added 190 stores. It was a very
componenttext: Yes. We'll start with Mexico. The one slowing trend has been the government spending. The spending from the consumer has been very solid. We saw good gains all across our network whether it was in the north or the south. We added 190 stores. It was a very good year for the Comex team, up high single digits for the year, so that was really a job well done by them. In Central America, we're in 7 small countries there. Of those 7, all 7 had positive year-over-year growth. In 2 of them, we had particularly high-growth rates, but that was the introduction of our new GLIDDEN product down there, and that was specifically Panama and Costa Rica. We would expect to grow faster in those 2 particular countries than we would the others. The others should be at a GDP kind of run rate. But overall, I would say both Mexico and Central America continue to be good markets for us overall.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on U.S. architectural, and I'm sorry if I missed this, but can you give us a sense as to how that business performed in the big-box channel, also retail stores? Also any benefit from the warmer weather in the country during the fourth quart
componenttext: Okay. And then on U.S. architectural, and I'm sorry if I missed this, but can you give us a sense as to how that business performed in the big-box channel, also retail stores? Also any benefit from the warmer weather in the country during the fourth quarter? And also, how would you characterize the pricing environment by channel at current?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we covered a lot of this originally, but the combined U.S., Canada stores network was slightly to flat. It was obviously held back by Canada, so that was our challenge there. We've had a positive growth with our DIY partners in the quarter. T
componenttext: Yes, I think we covered a lot of this originally, but the combined U.S., Canada stores network was slightly to flat. It was obviously held back by Canada, so that was our challenge there. We've had a positive growth with our DIY partners in the quarter. There was probably some material improvement due to weather, but not as much as you would think because obviously, they're destocking at that period of time. So they probably took that opportunity to continue to move down. But all in all, we do think weather was a positive in the fourth quarter. And then we talked about the dealers just recently. So I think overall, we've been performing slightly under the market. And if you say the market was 2% to 3%, we were one tick below that.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Nils Wallin of CLSA.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Nils Wallin of CLSA.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. First, would you remind us where you are in achieving all the various Comex cost, revenue and Central America synergies?
componenttext: Yes. First, would you remind us where you are in achieving all the various Comex cost, revenue and Central America synergies?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. This is Michael, again. The cost synergies we laid out were $45 million to $50 million, and we are on a pace to beat that number. So that's good. On the sales synergies in the Mexican market, we said that number was going to be $40 million to $
componenttext: Yes, sure. This is Michael, again. The cost synergies we laid out were $45 million to $50 million, and we are on a pace to beat that number. So that's good. On the sales synergies in the Mexican market, we said that number was going to be $40 million to $50 million. Those are PPG products for the Comex legacy -- or the Comex concessionaire network. We are solidly on pace to achieve those numbers. And then the Central America number was $60 million to $70 million. And based this -- most recent quarter, I am very comfortable with that number that we put out there. It's obviously early. We just closed on that acquisition in July, but the fourth quarter is the busy season down there, and we had a very good fourth quarter in the Central American market.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just in terms of the cash deployment guidance, obviously, last quarter you've moved it up at the bottom end and then reiterated it this quarter. I'm curious as to how you're thinking about next -- in '16. What would be the factors that wo
componenttext: Got it. And then just in terms of the cash deployment guidance, obviously, last quarter you've moved it up at the bottom end and then reiterated it this quarter. I'm curious as to how you're thinking about next -- in '16. What would be the factors that would allow it or cause it to be below what you've done in '15 or above what you've done in '15? And then what you think the mix will be? Is it likely to be more repurchases or more repurchases than M&A? Or is the mix likely to change?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Nils, it's Frank. So yes, if you look at what we did in '15, we basically came in at half of what the midpoint of the range we reiterated. So $1.15  billion as compared with $2 billion to $2.5 billion for the 2-year period. And as always, the mix be
componenttext: Okay, Nils, it's Frank. So yes, if you look at what we did in '15, we basically came in at half of what the midpoint of the range we reiterated. So $1.15  billion as compared with $2 billion to $2.5 billion for the 2-year period. And as always, the mix between the share repurchase and the acquisitions will depend on what we have in the pipeline and the timing of any closing of any particular acquisition. We've continually said we have a really nice robust pipeline of things that we continue to look at around the various regions and the various businesses from an acquisition standpoint, and that would be our preference to do accretive acquisitions. But as always, in any given quarter, there -- that mix will change. And I think it's safe to assume that while we like to focus on the acquisitions, that share repurchases will continue to be an integral part of our capital deployment strategy and no reason to believe that will not continue including this quarter.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just, also, what would -- would it just be the acquisition timing that would cause it to be above or below that midpoint? Or is there something else?
componenttext: Got it. And just, also, what would -- would it just be the acquisition timing that would cause it to be above or below that midpoint? Or is there something else?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we look at the whole landscape between what we have available in the acquisition pipeline and also in the deployment. And really, it starts with what our cash from operations that we generate is going to be. And what we've said is we came up with th
componenttext: Well, we look at the whole landscape between what we have available in the acquisition pipeline and also in the deployment. And really, it starts with what our cash from operations that we generate is going to be. And what we've said is we came up with that range because we know how much cash we will have to deploy, and we fully intend to be in the midpoint of that range. And the only thing that will change the mix is the timing of the acquisitions. But the absolute dollars we intend to bring in are within that $2 billion to $2.5 billion range.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Laurence Alexander of Jefferies.
componenttext: The next question comes from Laurence Alexander of Jefferies.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Dan Rizzo on for Laurence. Just one question. So some of your competitors have talked about going from sole sourcing to dual sourcing as a means to reduce raw materials cost. Is that something you guys are looking into or would it be suitable for
componenttext: This is Dan Rizzo on for Laurence. Just one question. So some of your competitors have talked about going from sole sourcing to dual sourcing as a means to reduce raw materials cost. Is that something you guys are looking into or would it be suitable for you? I mean, how much of your raw materials are currently sole sourced?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I wouldn't want to get into the percentage of either one of those. But I would tell you that we are consistently working with our suppliers to have maximum flexibility on how we formulate and how we work with our suppliers. So I would tell you we're
componenttext: Well, I wouldn't want to get into the percentage of either one of those. But I would tell you that we are consistently working with our suppliers to have maximum flexibility on how we formulate and how we work with our suppliers. So I would tell you we're very comfortable with where we are.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one more quick one. I think you indicated that you opened 190 new stores in Mexico to Comex in 2015. Is that going to be the pace going forward? Is that going to moderate at all? Or I mean, is it accelerating? Some color...
componenttext: Okay. And then one more quick one. I think you indicated that you opened 190 new stores in Mexico to Comex in 2015. Is that going to be the pace going forward? Is that going to moderate at all? Or I mean, is it accelerating? Some color...

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're expecting to open up 150 to 170 stores in 2016. So the -- we originally thought we'd do 170 this year. We actually did 190, so we may have pulled forward 1 or 2. But I still think we're going to be in a similar type of a range.
componenttext: We're expecting to open up 150 to 170 stores in 2016. So the -- we originally thought we'd do 170 this year. We actually did 190, so we may have pulled forward 1 or 2. But I still think we're going to be in a similar type of a range.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Dmitry Silversteyn of Longbow Research.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Dmitry Silversteyn of Longbow Research.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: A lot of my questions have been answered, but I'd like to follow-up on a couple of points. First of all, I mean, in fourth quarter aerospace weakness that you mentioned, was that related due to newbuilds or was that on the rebate part of the business? I k
componenttext: A lot of my questions have been answered, but I'd like to follow-up on a couple of points. First of all, I mean, in fourth quarter aerospace weakness that you mentioned, was that related due to newbuilds or was that on the rebate part of the business? I know they're usually 50-50 for you, but I was just wondering where the weakness in the quarter came from.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the weakness was really one part of it. I'll divide it into 2 parts. One part of it was because in the fourth quarter 2014, we had a government entity double order. Whether they try to use up all their budget or not, we're not that -- we're not able
componenttext: Yes, the weakness was really one part of it. I'll divide it into 2 parts. One part of it was because in the fourth quarter 2014, we had a government entity double order. Whether they try to use up all their budget or not, we're not that -- we're not able to predict, but we do know they double ordered. And then the other half of the slowdown was due to our sealants business. We have a customer that has -- that had a large new plane that they were working on, and they've gotten more consistent in ordering, and their work practices have gotten slightly better. So their -- what I would call, their waste has declined marginally. So now that that's more stable, we see them returning back to a year-over-year growth. The only thing about aerospace is the general aviation market is very strong for the big planes and slightly weak for the little planes.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, okay. So it sounds like it was more on newbuilds rather than sort of maintenance. So it would imply that the overall industry is still in pretty good shape?
componenttext: Right, okay. So it sounds like it was more on newbuilds rather than sort of maintenance. So it would imply that the overall industry is still in pretty good shape?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Boeing is expected. I think you probably listened to their commentary. Both guys are trying to increase production rates. They both have 8-year backlogs, so it's not like they don't have the business.
componenttext: Yes, Boeing is expected. I think you probably listened to their commentary. Both guys are trying to increase production rates. They both have 8-year backlogs, so it's not like they don't have the business.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we do expect aerospace to return to growth as Michael mentioned earlier. And again, just to give you the Q4 '14 comp, we were up high single digits in aerospace last year. That's the comp Michael is comparing against.
componenttext: Yes, we do expect aerospace to return to growth as Michael mentioned earlier. And again, just to give you the Q4 '14 comp, we were up high single digits in aerospace last year. That's the comp Michael is comparing against.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. On the Comex store openings, are these being opened by existing concessionaires? Are you signing new concessionaires or are these sort of company-owned stores, I guess, for lack of a better word? And just trying to understand the sort of where the
componenttext: Got it. On the Comex store openings, are these being opened by existing concessionaires? Are you signing new concessionaires or are these sort of company-owned stores, I guess, for lack of a better word? And just trying to understand the sort of where the source of growth is and how it's being supported by corporate versus concessionaires.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: There are no company-owned stores in Mexico. We have a dedicated concessionaire network. We do not ever plan to be in the company store business in Mexico. It is a combination of both our long -- some of our long-term concessionaire partners as well as so
componenttext: There are no company-owned stores in Mexico. We have a dedicated concessionaire network. We do not ever plan to be in the company store business in Mexico. It is a combination of both our long -- some of our long-term concessionaire partners as well as some new ones. So we have a lot of people that would like to have a store, and so we are very, very selective about finding those entrepreneurs that are going to live, eat, sleep, selling Comex paint. And that's -- our desire is to make sure we find the right people, and it is a combination of both existing and new.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So it sounds like sort of the hopper is being filled by people on the ground in Mexico, and then it's sort of up to you to figure out who gets it and who doesn't. Is that how the business model works?
componenttext: Okay. So it sounds like sort of the hopper is being filled by people on the ground in Mexico, and then it's sort of up to you to figure out who gets it and who doesn't. Is that how the business model works?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So this is definitely owned by Marcos Achar and his leadership team. All I do is bless it, but they are way better at this than anybody else.
componenttext: So this is definitely owned by Marcos Achar and his leadership team. All I do is bless it, but they are way better at this than anybody else.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Got it. Good to hear. And speaking of packaging and the shares that you picked up there inside of the can, I'm assuming you talked about sort of gaining shares in Europe last year and I guess in 2015, it was more the turn of the U.S., if I underst
componenttext: Got it. Got it. Good to hear. And speaking of packaging and the shares that you picked up there inside of the can, I'm assuming you talked about sort of gaining shares in Europe last year and I guess in 2015, it was more the turn of the U.S., if I understand your commentary correctly. So what -- I know that back a couple of years ago when you had your special day on packaging, you talked about 0 percentage inside the can market share in the U.S. What is your market share in the U.S. currently with this non-intent BPA transition taking place?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what we told you is that we had 3% global market share. I don't know that I want to get into what our market share is now, but I would call 3% not too material, and what we have now is definitely material. But it's a substantial double-digit kind of
componenttext: Well, what we told you is that we had 3% global market share. I don't know that I want to get into what our market share is now, but I would call 3% not too material, and what we have now is definitely material. But it's a substantial double-digit kind of increase, and our customers are excited about what we bring to the table from a technology standpoint. More importantly, they're excited about our ability to launch flawlessly these new products and that gives them a lot of comfort in giving us the business.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, all right. On the Performance Coatings and fourth quarter margins, they were a little bit lighter than what I would have expected it and the year-over-year improvement wasn't what you saw in the previous 3 quarters. Was that just a matter of mix in
componenttext: Okay, all right. On the Performance Coatings and fourth quarter margins, they were a little bit lighter than what I would have expected it and the year-over-year improvement wasn't what you saw in the previous 3 quarters. Was that just a matter of mix in the aerospace business being not as strong in Performance Coatings? Or was there something else going on with margins there?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dmitry, the sole factor there was the fact that we lapped Comex. So for the other 3 quarters this year, Comex, which comes in at above segment margin, was a true adder. We only have 1 month of that benefit in Q4 because we closed the Comex acquisition in
componenttext: Dmitry, the sole factor there was the fact that we lapped Comex. So for the other 3 quarters this year, Comex, which comes in at above segment margin, was a true adder. We only have 1 month of that benefit in Q4 because we closed the Comex acquisition in November last year. So...

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so that was entirely Comex-related, so fine. And on the glass part of the business, I'm assuming it's the lower energy costs that are driving the mid-teens margins that you haven't seen as far back as my model goes to 2001?
componenttext: Okay, so that was entirely Comex-related, so fine. And on the glass part of the business, I'm assuming it's the lower energy costs that are driving the mid-teens margins that you haven't seen as far back as my model goes to 2001?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. The energy -- most of the energy in glass is on an index, and so this is coming from true pricing in the marketplace. As you know, the supply and demand is relatively tight. One of our competitors closed a furnace in California. We sold our facility i
componenttext: No. The energy -- most of the energy in glass is on an index, and so this is coming from true pricing in the marketplace. As you know, the supply and demand is relatively tight. One of our competitors closed a furnace in California. We sold our facility in the Midwest. And so with the reduction in industry capacity, pricing has been attractive in that segment.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay, that's very helpful. And then finally -- as a sort of longer term, as I think about your cash flow, your working capital as a percentage of sales really has come down meaningfully over the last 5 years. I think it's almost half of what it us
componenttext: Got it. Okay, that's very helpful. And then finally -- as a sort of longer term, as I think about your cash flow, your working capital as a percentage of sales really has come down meaningfully over the last 5 years. I think it's almost half of what it used to be as a percentage of sales at just over 6% here in 2015. Do you have a longer-term goal? Or is this a level that you're happy with? Or is there an expectation that maybe given all the growth in this you have, that working capital will go up as a percentage of sales in 2, 3 years?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, our goal is still to bring working capital down as a percent of sales. And you're correct, over last 2 years, we brought down by about $300 million. About half of it was payables including supplier financing programs and about half was inventory, wh
componenttext: Well, our goal is still to bring working capital down as a percent of sales. And you're correct, over last 2 years, we brought down by about $300 million. About half of it was payables including supplier financing programs and about half was inventory, where we took out about 5 days of operational inventory this year. We've also improved the quality of the receivables by working down the percentage of past due, so we're pleased with that. But we still have several days to go we can get out of inventories and keep working on past due receivables. So the goal will be continue to bring down working capital by kind of, on average, 100 basis points a year for the next couple of years. And then we think we'll be kind of in line with the peer group.
