componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the PPG First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Andrew, and I will be your conference specialist today. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conferen
componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome to the PPG First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Andrew, and I will be your conference specialist today. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Scott Mentor, Director, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andrew. Good afternoon. This is Scott Minder, Director of Investor Relations. We appreciate your interest and PPG Industries, and we'll committed as teleconference to review PPG's wants first quarter 2016 financial results. John Amanda call fro
componenttext:
Thank you, Andrew. Good afternoon. This is Scott Minder, Director of Investor Relations. We appreciate your interest and PPG Industries, and we'll committed as teleconference to review PPG's wants first quarter 2016 financial results. John Amanda call from PPG our Michael McGarry, President and Chief Executive Officer; Frank Sklarsky, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Vince Morales, Vice President, Investor Relations and Treasurer.
Our comments related to the financial information released on Thursday, April 21, 2016. I will remind everyone that we posted detailed commentary and accompanying presentation slides on the Investor side of our website at www.ppg.com. The slides are also available on the webcast site for this call and provide supplemental support to the opening comments Michael will make shortly. Following Michael's perspective on the company results for the quarter, we will move to a Q&A session.
Most of the commentary and the discussion during this call may contain forward-looking statements, reflecting the company's current view of future events and the potential effect on PPG's operating and financial performance. These statements involve uncertainties and risks, which may cause actual results to differ. The company is under no obligation to provide subsequent updates to these forward-looking statements.
This presentation also contains certain non-GAAP financial measures. The company has provided in the appendix in the presentation materials, which are available on our website, reconciliations to these non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly the comparable GAAP financial measures. For additional information, please referred to PPG's filings with the SEC.
Now, let me introduce PPG President and Chief Executive Officer, Michael McGarry.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott, and good afternoon, everyone. I want to thank you for your continued interest in PPG. Today, we reported first quarter 2016 financial results. We achieved first quarter net sales of $3.7 billion and record adjusted earnings per diluted s
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott, and good afternoon, everyone. I want to thank you for your continued interest in PPG. Today, we reported first quarter 2016 financial results. We achieved first quarter net sales of $3.7 billion and record adjusted earnings per diluted share of $1.31. Overall, we continue to deliver strong financial results as evidenced by our adjusted earnings per diluted share growth in the quarter, which increased 11% versus the record established in the prior year. We achieved these results despite ongoing unfavorable foreign currency translation and continued uneven global economic and market conditions.
Several factors contributed to the record first quarter results, including earnings leverage on our organic sales volume growth, our continued heritage of cost management and acquisition-related sales and income. Additionally, we continue to utilize our strong balance sheet, deliver shareholder value, including first quarter 2016 share repurchases totaling $150 million. For the quarter, our average diluted shares outstanding declined by 2% year-over-year. 
Our strong quarterly results were aided by our own operational and strategic actions, including aggressive efforts to drive higher organic growth despite a mixed economic environment. We continue to accelerate our work on developing and commercializing new customer-driven technologies. This includes packaging coatings ongoing customer adoption of our new can coating technologies along with certain key technology adoptions in our protective coatings business. 
In addition, we are continuing to roll out of our enhanced customer branding initiatives. As you would expect from PPG, we continue to maintain our discipline over cost, including finalizing the remaining actions from our previously announced business restructuring program.
Now I will discuss specific business trends for the first quarter. Our net sales in local currencies increased about 4% while reported net sales were consistent with the prior year. Local currency net sales growth driven by acquisition-related sales of about 3% and sales volume growth of 1%. These gains were offset by unfavorable foreign currency translation of 4% or about $140 million in the first quarter. Our first quarter sales volumes increased 1%, consistent with the prior year's growth rate, reflecting a continuation of modest global economic trends, led by broadening European demand growth. Sales volume grew in emerging regions by 1%. Continued growth in Asia Pacific, including China, was partially offset by persistent market weakness in South America. Most of our business units entire sales volume in Asia led by increased market demand for PPG's new technologies in our packaging and automotive refinish coatings businesses along with growth in protective coatings. 
Automotive OEM sales in Asia were tempered primarily due to a strong prior year comparable period where PPG experienced above market, double-digit [indiscernible] volume increases. We expect second quarter emerging regions sales volume growth rate to improve the [indiscernible] in line increases in most businesses in Asia and modest overall improvements and Latin America. 
Volumes in the U.S. and Canada region were slightly higher versus prior year and represented sequential improvement compared to the prior 2 quarters. Regional demand trends continue to be mixed by business and country with ongoing demand softness in certain markets within Canada.
In the region, sales volumes grew in our packaging and automotive refinishing coatings business, along with modest growth in our architectural coatings business. Aerospace sales volume declined primarily due to lower commercial demand and continued customer inventory management actions. 
Looking ahead, we anticipate further incremental improvements in regional growth rates in the second quarter. Building upon the month of March we tend to have the strongest sales volume growth within the quarter. 
Regionally, our highest first quarter sales volume growth rate was in Europe, Middle East and Africa, which delivered over 3% growth. We continue to experience a broadening improvement in Europe demand with our fifth consecutive quarter improving growth rates. PPG volume growth rates were positive across in Europe with most countries improving year-over-year. Despite overall growth this quarter, regional demand levels remain uneven. 
Improved performance in our architectural coatings EMEA business added to continued strong performance in our packaging and automotive OEM coating business in a region primarily due to continued customer adoption of PPG's market-leading technologies and related world-class product, services and support. Architectural growth was led by gains in the U.K. and Benelux countries with year-over-year growth trends. We remain optimistic for future economic driven demand expansion in the EMEA region. 
Despite recent improvements, regional demand remains well below prerecession levels and we continue to see signs of ongoing modest improvement in various economic subsectors. During the past several years, we've completed significant actions to reduce our overall regional cost structure. Similar to our experience in the past several quarters, we expect strong income leverage on any incremental sales volume growth.
I would like to take -- provide a quick update on foreign currency translation. As I mentioned earlier, during the quarter, unfavorable foreign currency translation lowered sales by approximately $140 million in pretax income by about $15 million. This primarily related to the Mexican peso and the Canadian dollar but included other currencies as well such as Europe. Based on current exchange rates, we anticipate full year unfavorable foreign currency translation to lower net sales by $200 million to $260 million and income by $30 million to $40 million. This is a decrease from the figure that we provided during our fourth quarter 2015 earnings call in January. This change reflects the strengthening of several foreign currencies versus the U.S. dollar during the first quarter.
Shifting to earnings. Year-over-year adjusted earnings per diluted share increased 11% to a new first quarter record of $1.31, including unfavorable foreign currency translation. This marks the 13th consecutive quarter at double-digit percentage earnings for diluted share growth, and was achieved despite record performance in the first quarter of 2015. This trend of strong increases in quarterly earnings per diluted share is a reflection of the success of our business portfolio transformation actions taken over the past several years, including the successful integration and synergy achievement of several major acquisitions.
For the quarter, Performance Coatings segment sales declined by 1% and segment income was up more than 6%. Contributing to the results were higher acquisition-related sales and income, primarily from Le Joint Francais, [indiscernible] microwave, strong income leverage on higher sales volume and benefits from business restructuring, partially offset by unfavorable foreign currency translation. Segment income included approximately $15 million of incremental growth-related spending in architectural U.S. and Canada. I'm pleased to report that we're currently launching several new products within many of our domestic national account partner store networks. These launches include new premium products at some national accounts as well as improved product formulation and different phased product label.
Industrial Coatings segment sales were up 2% and segment earnings increased 9%. Earnings leverage from organic sales volume growth, acquisition-related sales and income, along with disciplined cost management were partially offset by unfavorable foreign currency translation. Acquisition-related growth was primarily from the [indiscernible] code and IBC industrial businesses acquired in 2015. These businesses continue to deliver strong financial results. They provide an excellent platform for future global business firm. 
[indiscernible] segment sales declined 2% and earnings declined by 7% versus the prior year. Higher selling prices and cost management actions were offset by lower sales volumes, $8 million in repair-related expenses due to our plant facility outage and lower equity earnings. Despite the lower sales volume, underlying flat glass demand remained solid. Additional segment and regional details can be found in the presentation materials.
Overall, our business performed well in the first quarter as we continue to manage against a mixed global economic backdrop, continuing to focus our efforts on improving organic growth rates through enhanced product innovation, customer branding strategies. Remain diligent over our costs and on pace to achieve the previously announced savings from our ongoing business restructuring program. 
Finally, our balance sheet remains strong and we are committed to deploying between $2 billion and $2.5 billion of cash in years 2015 and 2016 combined on acquisitions and share repurchase. 
In the first quarter, we repurchased $150 million of our stock bringing the total to $900 million for the 2-year period to date, coupled with the approximately $400 million paper acquisitions in 2015, PPG has deployed about $1.3 billion on earnings accretive actions against the started to date. We have a strong global pipeline of acquisition candidates across various end-use markets.
In addition to share repurchases and acquisitions, PPG remains committed to sustainable dividend increases as part of our capital allocation strategy. Today, our Board of Directors approved the dividend increase of $0.04 per share, bringing the quarterly dividend to $0.40 per share. This represents an 11% increase versus the prior quarterly dividend. Our last quarterly dividend increase was 7% in the second quarter 2015. 
As you can say by our actions and continued strong financial results, we remain focused on driving additional growth aimed at creating shareholder value. This concludes our prepared remarks. Once again, we appreciate your interest in PPG, and now Andrew, would you please open the line for questions.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Frank Mitsch of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Frank Mitsch of Wells Fargo.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, I was intrigued by your comment about March being the best volume month of the 3 in Q1. Can you give us an idea as to where that was and what that suggests for Q2 and beyond? Are we looking at PPG getting higher than a 1% of volume growth in 2016
componenttext: Michael, I was intrigued by your comment about March being the best volume month of the 3 in Q1. Can you give us an idea as to where that was and what that suggests for Q2 and beyond? Are we looking at PPG getting higher than a 1% of volume growth in 2016?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Frank, let's start with the obvious question. We're certainly not happy with the 1% growth. But we're in the very early stages of our growth programs, so the BPA-NI for packaging coatings. Sure, we'll get questions on that. But that's progressing we
componenttext: Well, Frank, let's start with the obvious question. We're certainly not happy with the 1% growth. But we're in the very early stages of our growth programs, so the BPA-NI for packaging coatings. Sure, we'll get questions on that. But that's progressing well. The OEM Compaq process continues to do well. Refinish, waterborne. So I'd say that's the first commentary. The second one, which is March. March, we had a nice start to the paint season. Clearly, we're anticipating that this is going to be a better paint season than we had last year. So that was a manifestation of that. Also, you had the uneven and uncertain return from the Chinese New Year. People were worried about that. So we were -- and we tried to tell you that we had a good order book coming in the Chinese New Year at our last call. We did see that coming out of Chinese New Year. So we did see good growth there. And I think the other one is the broadening of the growth rate in Europe. That was a nice win there as well. So altogether, I would say that we are closer to 2% to 3% growth in March versus the 1% that we reported in the overall quarter.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. As I look at Slide 9 and the auto forecast now. Obviously, we've been spoiled in expecting PPG to outpace the overall industry and in Q1, I guess, partly due to a difficult comp, the company matched the overall industry rather than exceed
componenttext: Okay. All right. As I look at Slide 9 and the auto forecast now. Obviously, we've been spoiled in expecting PPG to outpace the overall industry and in Q1, I guess, partly due to a difficult comp, the company matched the overall industry rather than exceeded the overall industry. However, as I look at that chart, it looks like Q2 China, you're going to see a maternal ramp up in activity. Am I reading this correctly?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the way I would think about this, Frank, is we've always said that we are not always going to outperform the industry. At some point, we're going to have some reversion of paint. If you remember last year, first quarter 2015, we were up 9% and Asi
componenttext: I think the way I would think about this, Frank, is we've always said that we are not always going to outperform the industry. At some point, we're going to have some reversion of paint. If you remember last year, first quarter 2015, we were up 9% and Asia was up much higher than that. So when I look at our automotive performance, we had 2 regions that outperformed, 1 region that underperformed and 1 region was at parity. So we were essentially at 1.7% growth rate for the industry. So I would say, when I think back about the 4 years of consecutive outperformance, if our team took a 1-quarter pause, not happy. But obviously, in the grand scheme of things, we continue to perform very well in automotive business. And I would expect that we're going to continue to see growth in Europe. Registrations are up 5%. So I would expect European builds to continue. Asia builds, India's really doing well. I'm not going to call the bottom in Brazil because I don't know where that is. But certainly, I think overall, we are pleased with the performance.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Ghansham Panjabi of Robert W.
componenttext: The next question comes from Ghansham Panjabi of Robert W.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually [indiscernible] in for ganja. Can you talk about pricing in auto OEM market globally? Are you seeing any price concessions given the decline in [indiscernible] and the budding power of customers in that business? And then, just more broadly,
componenttext: It's actually [indiscernible] in for ganja. Can you talk about pricing in auto OEM market globally? Are you seeing any price concessions given the decline in [indiscernible] and the budding power of customers in that business? And then, just more broadly, how should we think about pricing for the company as a whole in 2016?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's talk about pricing in general. At the end of the day, we have consistently been able to price in this environment. Last year, we had marginally positive price in an obviously very challenging environment. We have forecasted marginally, flat to margi
componenttext: Let's talk about pricing in general. At the end of the day, we have consistently been able to price in this environment. Last year, we had marginally positive price in an obviously very challenging environment. We have forecasted marginally, flat to marginally up again this year. The automotive segment, it's not really a fair thing to look at it on a piece by piece basis because most of what we have is new product technologies. So it's hard to compare the new technology versus the old. So overall, we've had very sophisticated automotive customers. We expect fair pricing. We have new technology. We expect to be paid appropriately for our new technology. And I would say both parties are very happy with the price and value and performance of the new products in the market today.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then for my next question, can you parse out growth in the various channels and in North America during the quarter? So I guess company-owned stores, national account independence in Canada, and how kind of your performance compared to the market?

componenttext: We have a little difficulty hearing you, let me repeat the question. I think you asked if we could parse out the different volume growth by U.S. architectural channel, is that correct?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, exactly.
componenttext: Yes, exactly.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So U.S. architectural channel. So overall, we had the low- to mid-single digits in that channel. It depends by region. So obviously, the one that continues to go backwards is, and I was surprised as a dealer -- independent dealer channel, that's an area w
componenttext: So U.S. architectural channel. So overall, we had the low- to mid-single digits in that channel. It depends by region. So obviously, the one that continues to go backwards is, and I was surprised as a dealer -- independent dealer channel, that's an area where -- that is a shrinking environment. You have the small owners of hardware stores and paint shops over time losing share to the big boxes and to the company-owned stores. So no change in that environment. I don't want to comment per se on how our retail customers are doing. I think it's up to them to comment how the retail customers are doing. But I will tell you that we had new product launches with dining and the [indiscernible] brand in Home Depot. The early signs it's just now getting into the market. The early signs are very positive. We have a super premium price point. A fair amount in [indiscernible],  also off to a good start. We'll  then complete at Walmart. So I think when we look at it from our perspective and I certainly have a lot of customers talk about it from their perspective. But we're pleased with what we're seeing. The company-owned stores varies by region and varies whether it's U.S. and Canada. But clearly, there's an opportunity for us to continue to deliver work roads going forward.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just one last one. Could you give us a detail on the weakness in the aerospace? Is it just small planes, large plans or both? And kind of what gives you confidence on an improvement in 2Q?
componenttext: Great. And just one last one. Could you give us a detail on the weakness in the aerospace? Is it just small planes, large plans or both? And kind of what gives you confidence on an improvement in 2Q?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So when you think about the aerospace business, you have several things to think about. So one of them is, 1 year ago, customers were having significant large programs. And as they ramped up, the last thing they want to do is stop their alignment la
componenttext: Sure. So when you think about the aerospace business, you have several things to think about. So one of them is, 1 year ago, customers were having significant large programs. And as they ramped up, the last thing they want to do is stop their alignment lack of product. And so they intended to over inventory. Now they're more at a steady state rate, and so that allows them to have more confidence in their build rate and their usage rate. So that's the short term hurdle. You do have some underlying softness. So if you take the oil and gas market, they fly a lot of helicopters. So obviously, they're flying less helicopters in this kind of environment, so you have less aftermarket sales and you have less new helicopter builds. So that would be one. And then generally, aviation, there's a lot of churn in the water as you can tell with one of our customers in Canada. So there's some things going on up there. So I think overall, we're on a short-term, one-quarter, two-quarter bump on the road. But I anticipate the second half of the year for aerospace to be much better. I would point out that the acquisitions that we made to aerospace acquisitions are performing very well. And their growth rate is above the growth rate of the overall business. So the outlook, I would say, is solid.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Christopher Parkinson of Credit Suisse.
componenttext: The next question comes from Christopher Parkinson of Credit Suisse.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you walk us through a little more detail on what you're seeing in the Mexican market in Comex? And particularly parse out architectural stores and industrial energy, government spending, and just overall, what assumptions are going into your double
componenttext: Could you walk us through a little more detail on what you're seeing in the Mexican market in Comex? And particularly parse out architectural stores and industrial energy, government spending, and just overall, what assumptions are going into your double Mexican GDP growth assumption?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We'll start with first quarter last year. We were up 10-plus percent in Mexico. And in this year, where up, I'd say, our sales were up 5% in Mexico. The GDP in Mexico is 2.2%. Our growth is being driven by several factors. The first one is the new s
componenttext: Sure. We'll start with first quarter last year. We were up 10-plus percent in Mexico. And in this year, where up, I'd say, our sales were up 5% in Mexico. The GDP in Mexico is 2.2%. Our growth is being driven by several factors. The first one is the new store growth rate. Last year, we added 170 stores in Mexico for over 4000 stores. We're now, today, as we speak, over 4,100 stores and we will add another 170 stores there. So what we've been gaining a lot of share in Mexico, the co-match team when we bought them, had a very large concentration in market share in what I would call Central Mexico. They were underrepresented in southern Mexico and underrepresented in northern Mexico. But we have a U.S. retail partner that have stores in Mexico. So we recently introduced the store and store concept down there. That's allowed them to gain shares as well. So from the store side, it's about service and product availability. And that's doing very well. Certainly, government spending has softened. And a lot of that is related to projects the government is trying to reduce spending given the price of oil. But there are elections coming up. So I would tell you that we're going to wait and see how it plays out. But historically in Mexico, when they have elections, the local politicians try to spruce things up to make things look a little bit better. And obviously, if they do that, it will be very happy to participate as we have a very significant share of Mexico.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I get an item [indiscernible] events. One of the synergies [indiscernible] we did Mark, when we did the acquisition was the revenue synergies that, that's what we we added subsequent to the acquisition. We are doing very well in our protective coating
componenttext: If I get an item [indiscernible] events. One of the synergies [indiscernible] we did Mark, when we did the acquisition was the revenue synergies that, that's what we we added subsequent to the acquisition. We are doing very well in our protective coating sales into Mexico, which is one of the synergies we targeted. So that is another add to their growth rate.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And just a quick follow up. You obviously already had a few shipments from billions. Could you just give us a quick update on the agreement, ramp up outlook et cetera, going forward, and just generally, how do you feel about these pro
componenttext: That's very helpful. And just a quick follow up. You obviously already had a few shipments from billions. Could you just give us a quick update on the agreement, ramp up outlook et cetera, going forward, and just generally, how do you feel about these prospects versus, let's say, maybe a year ago?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would tell you that we have tripled our purchases from billions in Q1 versus 4Q. But we're not satisfied with the build rate, if you will. We think they can deliver more. Obviously, they're successful in selling other places besides PPG. But overa
componenttext: Well, I would tell you that we have tripled our purchases from billions in Q1 versus 4Q. But we're not satisfied with the build rate, if you will. We think they can deliver more. Obviously, they're successful in selling other places besides PPG. But overall, the product quality continues to get better. The consistency gets better. And we are using it. We recently started bringing it into other regions besides U.S. and Central America and Latin America. So the usage runs, obviously, we started in Asia. But I would tell you overall, we've been pleased. But we've certainly challenged the [indiscernible] group to continue to work harder to bring the production rate up to a higher level.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The production rate has ramped significantly over the last 6 month. They're running very good yields and they just need to ramp up their pace a bit more.
componenttext: The production rate has ramped significantly over the last 6 month. They're running very good yields and they just need to ramp up their pace a bit more.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from David Begleiter of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: The next question comes from David Begleiter of Deutsche Bank.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Mike, how do you expect the recent rise in oil prices to the impact PPG? When will it begin to impact PPG?
componenttext: Hey, Mike, how do you expect the recent rise in oil prices to the impact PPG? When will it begin to impact PPG?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, David, I would first start by saying that as you know, we always tell you that we pool raw materials 6 to 9 months, it takes us 6 to 9 months to pull it through. So we're still pulling through the lower prices that we saw in 3Q-4Q. So that's -- if y
componenttext: Well, David, I would first start by saying that as you know, we always tell you that we pool raw materials 6 to 9 months, it takes us 6 to 9 months to pull it through. So we're still pulling through the lower prices that we saw in 3Q-4Q. So that's -- if you look in for that positive -- the second thing is, oil bounced -- if you think about where it started in Q1 and where it finished in Q1, it kind of bounced down, came back a little bit. But I'd say overall, it's too early to see where that's going. I mean, there's a lot of uncertainty in the market. Obviously, we're not oil traders but you could read the same thing as we read as far as oil. So we are not displeased with where we are going through that raw material statement.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Mike, overall, do you think your margins are near peak or can they go higher with operating leverage, offsetting maybe a little bit of cost contemplation here?
componenttext: And Mike, overall, do you think your margins are near peak or can they go higher with operating leverage, offsetting maybe a little bit of cost contemplation here?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're certainly not at peak. Don't forget, we still have the savings for Europe. We said for the full year, I think it was $70 million that we're going to pull through in Europe. So that's one. Two, you have significant earnings leverage when we get
componenttext: Yes. We're certainly not at peak. Don't forget, we still have the savings for Europe. We said for the full year, I think it was $70 million that we're going to pull through in Europe. So that's one. Two, you have significant earnings leverage when we get volume recovery in Europe. Obviously, you saw the margins expansion in this quarter. That was driven by several things of leverage in Europe, restructuring savings, acquisition synergies, some modest raw material benefits. But overall, I still think that we could do better and certainly our team thinks we can do better.

componenttextpreview: Well, one thing we do is we have a significant insight because of our share with some of these customers. So we are able to -- I don't want to call it a vendor managed inventory, but we have a significant insight into what they're stocking. The growth rat
componenttext: Well, one thing we do is we have a significant insight because of our share with some of these customers. So we are able to -- I don't want to call it a vendor managed inventory, but we have a significant insight into what they're stocking. The growth rate for the large -- if you think Boeing and Airbus obviously, have big backlogs but their build rate is flat to marginally down. And that is obviously, when you think about their inability to get production rates up, it's frustrating for us. I can't imagine how frustrating it must be internally for them. But that's the 2 ways we look at that.

componenttext: I think that's a reasonable expectation. As we've always said, it's impossible to predict large ones. They have a pipeline that looks very similar to the pipeline we had last year. We had 7 deals that had about $400 million in sales. I would expect to see a similar level of activity this year. And I think you'll have -- you'll see that as we go through the year.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: What is the net flows from asbestos this year? And do you still think you'll settle your asbestos liabilities?
componenttext: What is the net flows from asbestos this year? And do you still think you'll settle your asbestos liabilities?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, this is Frank. Jeff, we do expect that we're going to settle up in the first half of the year before the end of the first half of the year. And consistent with what we've said in the past and what you'll see when we file our Q over we laid it out, w
componenttext: Jeff, this is Frank. Jeff, we do expect that we're going to settle up in the first half of the year before the end of the first half of the year. And consistent with what we've said in the past and what you'll see when we file our Q over we laid it out, we've got about $500 million of cash going out initially with the option to pay out an additional amount of cash which represents the present value of the future obligations discounted at 5.5%. We'll obviously evaluate economic conditions at that time to determine whether we could take advantage of that discount that could potentially be attractive for us to do so. So the growth being something over $800 million but then almost immediately, we will start on a quarterly basis through adjusting our estimated taxes. And we'll over, ensuing few quarters, achieve a benefit that will bring the net cash outflow in total to about $500 million. That would assume -- if you were to assume that we took advantage of the discounted annuity. So that would be the way we will look at it. And of course, we have the donating of the PPG stock on [indiscernible] trust in addition to that. And Jeff, we have that stock at about $22. So if you do the math, it's about 2.8 million shares. So we're looking at somewhere in the $50 million range. The stock in our share count already will remain in our share count going forward.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: But again, that $50 million is included in the amount today [indiscernible].
componenttext: But again, that $50 million is included in the amount today [indiscernible].

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then for my follow-up, your gross margin last year expanded at 110 basis points. And this quarter, it expanded 1 60 even though you had no sales growth. But last year, your currency effects were negative 7 each quarter. And this quarter,
componenttext: Okay, great. And then for my follow-up, your gross margin last year expanded at 110 basis points. And this quarter, it expanded 1 60 even though you had no sales growth. But last year, your currency effects were negative 7 each quarter. And this quarter, maybe it was a little less than negative 4%. Is there a link between the smaller currency pressure and the widening of the gross margin, or is it not linked? And if they're not linked, why did your gross margin qualitatively advance versus what you were achieving last year?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a good inversion. Despite the fact that we still, the currency headwind was a little lower than we expected, it was still a headwind in Q1 versus prior year. I think it was a combination of factors. One, we've taken some additional benefit this yea
componenttext: That's a good inversion. Despite the fact that we still, the currency headwind was a little lower than we expected, it was still a headwind in Q1 versus prior year. I think it was a combination of factors. One, we've taken some additional benefit this year from restructuring that would not have taken place in last year's first quarter because the restricted [indiscernible] was really just getting underway at that point first-half year. So there's that piece of it. We had some manufacturing productivity. We've moved more aggressively, obviously, particularly in Europe on rationalizing [indiscernible] shared service from the administrative side. Acquisitions with a nice passthrough of the margins from those acquisitions was also an uplift as those acquisitions provided some margin a little bit above the corporate average. So the combination of factors plus admittedly, as we have said before, a modest amount of raw material savings in the first half of this year continuing what we saw in the back half of last year, all that contributed to the 110 basis points.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: 106 basis points year-over-year.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: But did the change in the smaller currency headwind benefit your gross margin?
componenttext: But did the change in the smaller currency headwind benefit your gross margin?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say on a relative basis, it was still a headwind. And so from an absolute standpoint, the answer would be no. Even if you go back to last year's first quarter, that the headwind was materially different than it was in this year's first quarter, ev
componenttext: I would say on a relative basis, it was still a headwind. And so from an absolute standpoint, the answer would be no. Even if you go back to last year's first quarter, that the headwind was materially different than it was in this year's first quarter, even though this year's first quarter was a little less than what we might have expected.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Duffy Fischer with Barclays.
componenttext: The next question comes from Duffy Fischer with Barclays.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question just around Europe. Seeing some recovery there. Could you kind of tease out where you're seeing that recovery? And then in architectural in Europe, are you growing with the market or faster than the market over there?
componenttext: Question just around Europe. Seeing some recovery there. Could you kind of tease out where you're seeing that recovery? And then in architectural in Europe, are you growing with the market or faster than the market over there?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let's take it by country, Duffy, just to add a little more color to it. So starting with the U.K., Ireland, it is growing faster than the company average and taking share, clearly. Then you take France growing lower than the company average but taki
componenttext: Well, let's take it by country, Duffy, just to add a little more color to it. So starting with the U.K., Ireland, it is growing faster than the company average and taking share, clearly. Then you take France growing lower than the company average but taking share. Then you take central Europe, I would say slightly below the company average, maintaining share. That's kind of the architectural landscape,,  if you will. But then if you get in to our other businesses, we have a broadening recovery. So southern Europe, Spain, Italy, for example, significantly accelerating growth quarter-over-quarter in all our businesses. And that's the benefit. We don't have architectural. We do have a little bit in Spain but very little. We have a little bit in Italy. But for [indiscernible] things were pretty small. So overall, [indiscernible] Southern Italy and southern Europe is doing very well and that's a net positive for us. The offset to that, of course, is Russia. Although I will tell you that we are outperforming in Russia, especially in our industrial business. They've done a really good job. They're trying to get more localization and so that has benefited us. The Middle East, I would say, slightly better than company average. And that encompasses all our business. Then I'd say our protective business is probably one of the ones that are doing pretty well in the Middle East.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Duffy, the slide in our presentation deck that shows the region or the e-map that shows the region by country year-over-year.
componenttext: Duffy, the slide in our presentation deck that shows the region or the e-map that shows the region by country year-over-year.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And then just on BPA. You've been taking some nice market share there. How long should we think about that trend lasting? Is that something that's got another 4 or 5 quarters? Or might it have another 8 to 10 quarters?
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And then just on BPA. You've been taking some nice market share there. How long should we think about that trend lasting? Is that something that's got another 4 or 5 quarters? Or might it have another 8 to 10 quarters?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would look at it just like I look at automotive. We had 4 years of automotive outperformance. This is technology that we're leading in. There's been 2 plants converted in France. We have the vast majority of that business. Now with the proposition
componenttext: Well, I would look at it just like I look at automotive. We had 4 years of automotive outperformance. This is technology that we're leading in. There's been 2 plants converted in France. We have the vast majority of that business. Now with the proposition 65 in California, there have been 6 plants converted in the U.S. And I would call our share at 5-plus out of those 6. And so you still have the whole wave with the rest of the U.S. to come. The food guide is just starting to convert probably the third quarter of last year. So you still have that coming on. So I think net-net, this is a long-term structural game. I mean, we used that only 3% share inside the can. You would think over time we would approach 25% or 30% share at a minimum. I certainly challenge the team to be better than that. But I would tell you, this is a secular change. These guys -- they don't change for 30 years and when they do change, it happens over time and we should expect to see this ramp up over the next several years.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Vincent Andrews of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: The next question comes from Vincent Andrews of Morgan Stanley.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to revisit the M&A conversation. And I guess my thought is that, obviously, there was a large transaction announced between your larger peers and the byproduct of that is that they are no longer competing with you for any M&A assets that might be
componenttext: I wanted to revisit the M&A conversation. And I guess my thought is that, obviously, there was a large transaction announced between your larger peers and the byproduct of that is that they are no longer competing with you for any M&A assets that might be out there. So I'm just wondering if the dialogue between yourself and those on that target list of yours is accelerating or changing in any way. And has there been any impact in the discussions from transactions that was recently put up on the board?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you have to evaluate these independently. The transaction multiple that was announced in the first quarter was a unique property and came with a unique price. And we certainly -- if anybody tries to argue for that price for PPG to pay, that
componenttext: Well, I think you have to evaluate these independently. The transaction multiple that was announced in the first quarter was a unique property and came with a unique price. And we certainly -- if anybody tries to argue for that price for PPG to pay, that will be a very short discussion. So we'll start their. The second thing I would say is, perhaps they could be out of the market for some period of time. But you know what, they have cash. That is easy to get and we're not going to assume that this is an open runaway for us. We're going to look at what our competition is. We have multiple people that are competing with these properties. So we will continue to evaluate that. But the bottom line is, we have not seen any increase in the number of people coming to us. I would tell you that overall, our mantra remains the same that we are very disciplined buyers and the business teams have to make a justification and the synergies have to be there. And that's the focus anytime we look at any acquisition.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: The next question comes from Don Carson of Susquehanna Financial.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Just a question on your architectural growth in U.S. and Canada. So you talked about low to mid single-digit growth. You think you're underperforming your market there? How would you characterize your overall market growth? And what kind of a sort of a snapback you see this quarter and into third quarter based on the weather?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Don, this is Vince. A little bit early to read and think into these, and we don't have enough data points yet to determine it by channel how we're performing versus some of the other folks. And March is a little bit typically of a murky month. We feel tha
componenttext: Don, this is Vince. A little bit early to read and think into these, and we don't have enough data points yet to determine it by channel how we're performing versus some of the other folks. And March is a little bit typically of a murky month. We feel that in the -- as Michael mentioned, we've got new products in some of the major home centers. We feel those products are good new products with good new branding. The independent dealer channel is a shrinking channel. Certainly around there. And as Michael mentioned at the beginning, we got to do better in our U.S. company-owned stores. And in Canada, we think we are at parity at minimum. But a little too early to call it one way or the other.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just to follow-up on your channel strategy. You talked about investing in branding. Is this designed more for your company-owned stores? And what kind of investment should we expect in your company-owned stores coming forward? Are you looki
componenttext: Okay. And then just to follow-up on your channel strategy. You talked about investing in branding. Is this designed more for your company-owned stores? And what kind of investment should we expect in your company-owned stores coming forward? Are you looking to open a certain number every year to sort of get that mix up above your 50% of your overall architectural sales volume in U.S. and Canada?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So when you think about the $15 million investment that we made, that is where the first quarter investment, that's a nonrecurring investment. We do have enhanced brand strategies that we are rolling out but that's incorporated where we might be repl
componenttext: Yes. So when you think about the $15 million investment that we made, that is where the first quarter investment, that's a nonrecurring investment. We do have enhanced brand strategies that we are rolling out but that's incorporated where we might be replacing dollar one with category A with category B. So there's no real step change there. We do open up. We expect to open up. We typically say 25, 50 stores in the U.S. and Canada. We'll be opening up 200 stores in Mexico. 170 to 200 stores. We'll be opening up stores in Europe as well. So that we will also be in that 20 to 25 range. And so we continue to evaluate opportunities to grow this business. But I'd say overall, I'm pleased with the performance there.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from P.J. Juvekar of Citi.
componenttext: The next question comes from P.J. Juvekar of Citi.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, I want to go back to the refinished business. What kind of growth are you seeing there? And can you break it down between price and volume? And then are MSOs getting bigger and bigger volume discounts?
componenttext: Michael, I want to go back to the refinished business. What kind of growth are you seeing there? And can you break it down between price and volume? And then are MSOs getting bigger and bigger volume discounts?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Let's start with the easy. When the MSOs they've been relatively constant. They'd like to have bigger. But everybody, every customer we have, once we get discount, but it's been relatively flat. When we think about our refinished business, it's not ju
componenttext: No. Let's start with the easy. When the MSOs they've been relatively constant. They'd like to have bigger. But everybody, every customer we have, once we get discount, but it's been relatively flat. When we think about our refinished business, it's not just the U.S. it's -- when we look at China, that is especially a good market for us. So they're shifting from solvents to water. There's a big tax in China on solvent-based products. So that's a positive for us. Historically, we do have positive price in our refinished business. You would expect that this year that we'll have positive price as well. Interesting enough, volumes in the U.S. is actually up. That is, miles driven is up 2%. Not only do we have miles driven up but you have distracted driving up eventually that I see about every day on my way home. So that's a positive. The other thing is when you look at what's happening with technology, our water-based product is outperforming in every region in the world. So even this Argentina right now, our business is growing in Argentina. One of our competitors vacated Brazil. We picked up a huge chunk of that business. One of our other competitors vacated Europe. We picked up a vast majority of that business. So we continued to perform in that regard. So when I think about one of the shining stars in PPG, think our refinishes is at the top of the list.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: To add to what Michael said. This is Frank. And we kind of solved it in the past. With our strong position over in Asia, particularly in China and our move from premium to midline offerings, we have an opportunity to really grow that business over the lon
componenttext: To add to what Michael said. This is Frank. And we kind of solved it in the past. With our strong position over in Asia, particularly in China and our move from premium to midline offerings, we have an opportunity to really grow that business over the long term because this production over 20 million units goes mostly still to that market. That carpark continues to grow whereas in developed regions, where we're also -- positions. The carpark is relatively steady, so you are depending upon miles driven, and things like that. But China has the additional benefit of adding a lot of units to the carpark. And so those growth rates, over the long term, bode well for the business overall.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And secondly, did the introduction of HDTV at Lowe's have any impact on your sales at Lowe's?
componenttext: Great. And secondly, did the introduction of HDTV at Lowe's have any impact on your sales at Lowe's?

componenttextpreview: Well, I think the way to think about that, P.J, is which price points do we compete in. And so I think the way we look at it is our total sales through our retail partner were up year-over-year, '15 versus '14. And I'm not unhappy with the first quarter p
componenttext: Well, I think the way to think about that, P.J, is which price points do we compete in. And so I think the way we look at it is our total sales through our retail partner were up year-over-year, '15 versus '14. And I'm not unhappy with the first quarter performance. And our relationship is very strong. And so I will tell you, that is obviously, a retail position and how they brand and how they position them. But overall, we're happy with our relationship at Lowe's.

componenttext: With a common consolidation in the number of suppliers into the DIY retail channel, you think we should expect some rebalancing among customers, some churn to see share go up and down more than we have in the past, for example? And if there is a divestment, let's say, out of the the [indiscernible] business, do you think you might end up with a new competitor in the space here that you might have to worry about?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, John, we don't speak for our customers. As Michael said earlier, in aerosourcing decisions that are typically there. I think we've got -- exhibited by the new products we're placing in through the channel that you're talking about this year. We alwa
componenttext: Well, John, we don't speak for our customers. As Michael said earlier, in aerosourcing decisions that are typically there. I think we've got -- exhibited by the new products we're placing in through the channel that you're talking about this year. We always have good relationships with those customers. But we're not at liberty to make sourcing decisions for them. With respect to the acquisition of German Valspar, we're not sure what the outcome of that will be. So that's not within our jurisdiction or our decision tree. So we'll leave that to the parties involved.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from James Sheehan of SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.
componenttext: The next question comes from James Sheehan of SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about your expectations for TiO2 prices? It looks like you may be going up a little bit here in the short-term. What's your outlook for the rest of the year on TiO2?
componenttext: Can you talk about your expectations for TiO2 prices? It looks like you may be going up a little bit here in the short-term. What's your outlook for the rest of the year on TiO2?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, James. TiO2, we've always said is a supply demand driven environment. When I think about what's going on in the overall global supply demand environment, you have additional capacity in China. You're soon to have additional capacity in Mexico. So fr
componenttext: Well, James. TiO2, we've always said is a supply demand driven environment. When I think about what's going on in the overall global supply demand environment, you have additional capacity in China. You're soon to have additional capacity in Mexico. So from that regard, that's obviously, more supply. Demand, if you look at Europe -- European TiO2 consumption is down about 15% from its peak. So net-net, even though euro volumes are recovering a little bit, they are still substantially down from where they were. Then of course, you have the material weakness in Brazil. The material weakness in -- most of Latin America, Russia. And so from a supply demand standpoint, I think we still see it as a balanced market. And I know they are out there running around with price increases announced. But if you remember, they've had price increase announcements for several quarters out of the past 2 to 3 years. And that's -- just because they announced it doesn't mean we're paying them. So overall, our goal, as you know, we've taken out of PPG, 10% of our TiO2 consumption as down because of substitution strategy, replacement of alternative products. And also, with the bringing in billions. So I know there's a lot of noise out there. But when we talk to our suppliers, we're trying to get them focused on supply and demand, and that's where we're going to stay on that topic. I know they're looking at -- they're not making any new money. By they didn't write us a check the last time when they were on the top of the cycle.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And could you also comment on demand trends you're seeing in various end markets in China?
componenttext: Great. And could you also comment on demand trends you're seeing in various end markets in China?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So obviously, automotive was up. Everybody sees those numbers. So good performance there. Industrial is a mixed bag, dependent upon which segment has anything to do with commodities as down. Heavy-duty equipment, down. Packaging, we're a little disa
componenttext: Sure. So obviously, automotive was up. Everybody sees those numbers. So good performance there. Industrial is a mixed bag, dependent upon which segment has anything to do with commodities as down. Heavy-duty equipment, down. Packaging, we're a little disappointed in the packaging output. It's rather pivotably flat with the consumer-driven economy, we would have thought that would've been up a little bit more. But we are gaining share there with our BPA non-intent products. So we could be doing better. If you look at refinished with Frank explained earlier, the carpark is growing when they made a nice move to the premium market we gained. We're now introducing some midtier products. So that should be a net positive. And it hasn't happened yet. But there is Comac, which expects to build an airplane at some point in time. They rolled it out the hangar but they rolled it back in the hangar. So those didn't fly. So I don't know when that will start. But obviously, we have a lot of content on that plane. So if it does get into production, we will be a net beneficiary of that. On the protective side, we are doing very well in protective in China. Marine, not bad. But you really have to balance that with the fact that the Korean Marine is just falling off a cliff. In fact, 2 of the 3 largest Korean shipbuilders did not even get a major order in Q1. But you have to balance what you see in China with the fact that Korea, which is where the big market is, is off. So I guess that would be my kind of a -- around the segment approach there.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just to reemphasize, James, that Michael talked about India. We are seeing very good growth in India across all of the markets in which we participate in. It's a smaller market for us but an important market. It has a very good growth trend right no
componenttext: I was just to reemphasize, James, that Michael talked about India. We are seeing very good growth in India across all of the markets in which we participate in. It's a smaller market for us but an important market. It has a very good growth trend right now.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Arun Viswanathan, RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question comes from Arun Viswanathan, RBC Capital Markets.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I was just maybe on [indiscernible] a little bit more. The 1% volume growth that you posted across the portfolio. I know you guys weren't satisfied by that. And maybe, can you help us understand what kind of visibility you have? Maybe on a couple of
componenttext: Yes. I was just maybe on [indiscernible] a little bit more. The 1% volume growth that you posted across the portfolio. I know you guys weren't satisfied by that. And maybe, can you help us understand what kind of visibility you have? Maybe on a couple of the larger businesses, OEM, refinished, arrow and architectural, why that would accelerate, as we go through the year. And are there some specific projects or something else specific to you guys?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll take a shot at that, Arun. If you look at our different businesses, we have a best visibility in both Marine, new-build and aerospace where we have a very long border cycle. We have a fairly concrete order patterns by our customers. In the midd
componenttext: Sure. I'll take a shot at that, Arun. If you look at our different businesses, we have a best visibility in both Marine, new-build and aerospace where we have a very long border cycle. We have a fairly concrete order patterns by our customers. In the middle, you would have some industrial customers, automotive customers, we're seeing good confidence, we'll call it a month's worth of orders with fairly good confidence. And then on the other side of the equation, would be architectural, including company-owned stores and independent dealers where people are walking in on a daily basis and your pattern certainly has a cadence to it. But it's not as predictable. So there we have, let's call it a few days worth of visibility. If you aggregate all of that, 50% to 60% of our business, we can see probably several weeks, if not a month or longer. And so that's what gives us our ability to forecast for you what we think.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then also as a follow-up, just curious. Are we still kind of expecting that overall volume growth could approach mid-single digits for the year? And I guess, where would you see the greatest amount of volume growth?
componenttext: Okay. And then also as a follow-up, just curious. Are we still kind of expecting that overall volume growth could approach mid-single digits for the year? And I guess, where would you see the greatest amount of volume growth?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we definitely expect improvement as we go throughout the year. Again, I think in Q1 of this year, we had some very difficult comps in some large businesses. Michael mentioned the almost 10% comp we had in automotive in Q1 year-over-year. That starts
componenttext: Well, we definitely expect improvement as we go throughout the year. Again, I think in Q1 of this year, we had some very difficult comps in some large businesses. Michael mentioned the almost 10% comp we had in automotive in Q1 year-over-year. That starts to wane as we go throughout the year. And again, we had, as Michael mentioned earlier, we have some easier weather comps than some of our businesses in the U.S. as we come up in Q2 and Q3. So there are our expectations, certainly as we move the needle more positively than we did in Q1.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly, if I may. On the FX side. I know that you had said that there were still a negative impact in Q1. Would that also wane as we go through the year? And do you expect that ultimately to potentially even get a benefit if we stay where w
componenttext: Okay. And then lastly, if I may. On the FX side. I know that you had said that there were still a negative impact in Q1. Would that also wane as we go through the year? And do you expect that ultimately to potentially even get a benefit if we stay where we are in the euro?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Arun. We see current rates across the board. It will definitely wane as we go through the year. So [indiscernible] will still be a headwind but a bit less than Q1 if they stay where they are and will continue to dwindle down as it goes through the ye
componenttext: Yes, Arun. We see current rates across the board. It will definitely wane as we go through the year. So [indiscernible] will still be a headwind but a bit less than Q1 if they stay where they are and will continue to dwindle down as it goes through the year. Positive and negative at some point in time. Well, it depends on the mix, because for the last few quarters, the biggest headwind was the euro with a little bit stronger euro than anticipated but a little bit weaker peso because of some of the oil-based factories there as well as some weakness in Latin America. So that mixed those change. So good one of the currencies turned positive at some point in time, sure. But overall, if you look at the whole basket, yes. The 140 on the top line the 15 [ph] you saw on the bottom line and in the first quarter, that'll be a little bit less. And then the numbers that Michael gave for the year, the 200 260 in the top line and the 30 to 40 bottom line dictates that at current rates, things will automatically come down. We'll see how that plays out if it plays [indiscernible] throughout the year. And I'll remind everybody, the guidance we gave in January was close to $600 million top line in the 70, 80 bottom line. So there's a significant improvement versus 3 months ago.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: The next question comes from Mike Harrison of Seaport Global Securities.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: I was wondering if you could give us an update on exactly where you are with some of the display resets you're doing at Lowe's. How much of that is complete? And do you have any metrics that you ca share with us in terms of the customer response? Either Lowe's or what you're seeing from the actual DIY customers that are going through.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I won't talk about, specifically, Lowe's. I'll talk about the industry in general when you look at the home centers. The typical way they do the recess is they start in the southern and western states and they work their way north. So if you think a
componenttext: Well, I won't talk about, specifically, Lowe's. I'll talk about the industry in general when you look at the home centers. The typical way they do the recess is they start in the southern and western states and they work their way north. So if you think about that, we're probably less than 1/3 of the way through it. Typically, they're all done by the end of May. So that's kind of the cadence that we'd be working on. Again, we don't want to talk for our customers. But the early indications that we saw, we were very pleased with the early turnover in the stores. But again, it's a small data set in Q1 because if you think about it, most of that's starting to get set mid-March. We only had 2 weeks in Q1 and then you'll have a, probably half of it, half to 2/3 of the quarter in the second quarter.

componenttext: Well, I think you have to look at it by country, right? So Mexico is still doing well and Mexico. Columbia, I would say, more flat line. Argentina is getting better. So that was the one positive. And even though Brazil is going down, we're actually going up because one of our competitors pulled out of Brazil. So that's been a positive from a refinished side.

componenttextpreview: I would say this is inning the bottom of the first, top of the second inning. So there's a lot of work to be done in this regard. You tend to have 1 customer on the beverage side as a leader and then most of the other guys tend to be followers. So we're o
componenttext: I would say this is inning the bottom of the first, top of the second inning. So there's a lot of work to be done in this regard. You tend to have 1 customer on the beverage side as a leader and then most of the other guys tend to be followers. So we're out in front with the leader in that area. And you have a couple of food guys that are more aggressive. So they move in a faster rate than the beverage guys have. And then I would say that -- on the near side, it's even on a slower ramp. So there's been a lot of practice done. There's been a lot of tests done. There's been a lot of work in that area. But as far as actual production, it is way, way early in the game for those guys.

componenttext: And yes, back to what Michael was saying before, too. Keep in mind, in businesses where we've typically outperformed in the recent past, you are restarting with a solid market share position. And those businesses were already kind of in a mature level. These has 2 advantages, this sector. Not only is it in its infancy in terms of adoption, we're also starting at a point in time where, as Michael said, very low share inside the cap. So everything is incremental share crossed early points of adoption, and that's what gives us the confidence. This is a multi-year trend and has a lot of legs to it for some time to come.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well first, let me say that this channel has been in a contraction mode for quite some time. I think if you take a look at our longer period of time, call it 5 or 7 years, the contraction has been more modest than the industry has expected. And definitely
componenttext: Well first, let me say that this channel has been in a contraction mode for quite some time. I think if you take a look at our longer period of time, call it 5 or 7 years, the contraction has been more modest than the industry has expected. And definitely, through the last couple of years, has accelerated somewhat, but it's lumpy. So there's not a linear path here. And right now, I think we're probably contracting somewhere between, let's call it 1% to 2% per year in the last couple of years to the market.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a long, long term play. I mean, obviously, as our retail partners get bigger, as the company-owned stores network get bigger, it's more challenged. As these people that own these stores, as their children do not want to be in the hardware business or
componenttext: It's a long, long term play. I mean, obviously, as our retail partners get bigger, as the company-owned stores network get bigger, it's more challenged. As these people that own these stores, as their children do not want to be in the hardware business or don't want to be in the paint store business, they tend to sell. So over time, this is just a demographic play that will continue to play out. But you're talking about 30, 40, 50 years. This isn't something that's going to be gone in 3 weeks or 3 years.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's a very good point. When we get the operating leverage but we're also, as a multi-year for going out improvement in working capital. And that also will help us improve the conversion -- the cash flow conversion. So we still have the opportunit
componenttext: I think it's a very good point. When we get the operating leverage but we're also, as a multi-year for going out improvement in working capital. And that also will help us improve the conversion -- the cash flow conversion. So we still have the opportunity to improve inventory levels. We're working on our complexity, which will improve days of inventory. Still have some room to improve our [Audio Gap] receivables that will help conversion. The other factor is that we have said in the recent past that our capital spending is more in a peak level now and will decline over the next 5 years. That will also improve our cash conversion as a percent of net income as a percent of depreciation. So all those factors considered actually bode well for cash conversion percentage over the next 3 to 5 years.

componenttext: And then when you look at industrial coatings, the value proposition to the customer, the mix that you have in your -- of between, what you call it, protecting services as opposed to decorating them or beautifying them. headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: I think, Lawrence, we do both. I think the coatings industry not only PPG, but we protect and beautify. So it's a dual purpose the coatings provides. I don't think there's a mix differential. On an automobile, it protects the surface and beautifies the vehicle itself. So most of our coatings do both.

And keep in mind, that everyday of inventory and payables is worth $25 million everyday of receivables worth $43 million. There's a lot of leverage on cash flow by improving it just a little bit.
