componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Robert Koort with Goldman Sachs.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Chris Evans on for Bob. On the negative pricing you guys showed, can you break out exactly which end markets you saw this pricing? Or kind of what the dynamic was across your portfolio?
componenttext: This is Chris Evans on for Bob. On the negative pricing you guys showed, can you break out exactly which end markets you saw this pricing? Or kind of what the dynamic was across your portfolio?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris, this is Michael. We're not going to get into the specifics by business unit. But what I will tell you is that typically, in our coatings portfolio, what you find is that larger, very sophisticated customers understand the raw material environment,
componenttext: Chris, this is Michael. We're not going to get into the specifics by business unit. But what I will tell you is that typically, in our coatings portfolio, what you find is that larger, very sophisticated customers understand the raw material environment, and we always work with them in a collaborative and constructive manner, whether it's a up pricing environment or a down raw material environment. And so the way to think about this is our larger customers might have seen a slight price reduction, whereas our smaller customers or the customers that go through distribution would be in a overall flat environment or slightly up. Overall, for the year, we had told you that we'd be in a flat pricing environment. And for the full year, we still expect that to be overall flat.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then -- and I guess, as raw materials move, sort of inflates, what are your expectations? And how do you think pricing -- your ability to get pricing kind of next year as TiO2 and propylene derivatives and a few others might work against you?
componenttext: And then -- and I guess, as raw materials move, sort of inflates, what are your expectations? And how do you think pricing -- your ability to get pricing kind of next year as TiO2 and propylene derivatives and a few others might work against you?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So right now, Chris, the tailwinds have certainly diminished. However, we have not really seen any real inflation yet except for a small pickup in TiO2. Certainly, a lot of the feedstocks are up since January 1. But again, we don't price in realtime. So w
componenttext: So right now, Chris, the tailwinds have certainly diminished. However, we have not really seen any real inflation yet except for a small pickup in TiO2. Certainly, a lot of the feedstocks are up since January 1. But again, we don't price in realtime. So we don't always get all the benefits on the way down, and we don't get all the prices on the way up. So again, we will work with our customers. We typically lag on the way down and lag on the way up. And I don't expect that this next cycle will be any different than what we have seen in the past.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And this is Vince. I want to add want one comment. If you look at our supply chain, many of our suppliers have expanded their margins over the past couple of years. So as -- if we do see inflation in oil or oil derivatives, we would expect the first cut t
componenttext: And this is Vince. I want to add want one comment. If you look at our supply chain, many of our suppliers have expanded their margins over the past couple of years. So as -- if we do see inflation in oil or oil derivatives, we would expect the first cut to come out of their pocket.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from John Roberts with UBS.
componenttext: The next question comes from John Roberts with UBS.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Were there any significant deals that you had hoped to close in the quarter, but maybe they fall into the fourth quarter?
componenttext: Were there any significant deals that you had hoped to close in the quarter, but maybe they fall into the fourth quarter?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, we don't provide speculation on deals or potential deals. I think Michael said we have an active M&A pipeline. We think, for the industry, it's very active. Hopefully, we can continue to use our cash in a constructive manner in -- with reference to
componenttext: John, we don't provide speculation on deals or potential deals. I think Michael said we have an active M&A pipeline. We think, for the industry, it's very active. Hopefully, we can continue to use our cash in a constructive manner in -- with reference to acquisitions. But if not, the fly will be share buybacks.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then we've come to think of cost cutting at PPG and productivity as sort of evergreen here, do you think after so many years of being so successful in your cost cutting and productivity, you're just so lean at this point that we're kind of reach
componenttext: Okay. And then we've come to think of cost cutting at PPG and productivity as sort of evergreen here, do you think after so many years of being so successful in your cost cutting and productivity, you're just so lean at this point that we're kind of reaching the end of the ability to bring additional cost cuts to the earnings bottom line?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, this is Frank. No, it's a good question, but the way we look at it, there are always opportunities for rationalization of our cost structure. As we continue to move more administrative cost into shared service environments, as we look at our overall
componenttext: John, this is Frank. No, it's a good question, but the way we look at it, there are always opportunities for rationalization of our cost structure. As we continue to move more administrative cost into shared service environments, as we look at our overall supply chain footprint, as we continue to integrate both recent and legacy acquisitions and look at our total administrative cost structure, we think there are still additional opportunities for the broad base and significant cost actions, which we would like to embark on over the next year. And while we don't have a specific number for you right now, we're looking at that very carefully, analyzing all the details and we'll get back to you in the near future in terms of what the exact numbers are and the benefits associated with any rationalization actions. But we still think there are ample opportunities for continuing to rationalize cost.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And John, this is Michael. As you know, being -- having productivity initiatives is a DNA of PPG. And every business unit is expected every year to come forward with productivity initiatives. So this isn't anything new, but we are certainly ratcheting up
componenttext: And John, this is Michael. As you know, being -- having productivity initiatives is a DNA of PPG. And every business unit is expected every year to come forward with productivity initiatives. So this isn't anything new, but we are certainly ratcheting up the attention in this area.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Frank Mitsch with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: The next question comes from Frank Mitsch with Wells Fargo.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, you referenced that this is the first time in a long time that you folks had to preannounce. I think it was '08 was the last time, and obviously, we were in for a really big rough patch in '09 as well. And given your results here in Q3 and given
componenttext: Michael, you referenced that this is the first time in a long time that you folks had to preannounce. I think it was '08 was the last time, and obviously, we were in for a really big rough patch in '09 as well. And given your results here in Q3 and given the outlook for 1% or 2% growth in Q4, do you have confidence in 2017 being a materially better year? And if so, why?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Frank, as you know, this is something that we haven't had to do in a long time. I appreciate you actually picking up on the exact year, 2008. But I feel confident that when I look around the global economy, I don't see anything ready to fall off the ta
componenttext: So Frank, as you know, this is something that we haven't had to do in a long time. I appreciate you actually picking up on the exact year, 2008. But I feel confident that when I look around the global economy, I don't see anything ready to fall off the table. I mean, we still see some of the same weaknesses that we've seen in the past. Brazil continues to be challenged. Russia continues to be challenged. There are continued weaknesses in other economies. Certainly, Korea remains challenged. But when I look across the big industries like automotive, we're still expecting automotive next year to be marginally up. Certainly, the U.S. is moving into the ninth inning, but Europe still has room to go on that. So no, I don't see anything like what we experienced in the back half of 2008. So I'm confident that we will see improvement in 2017.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Frank, this is the other Frank. There are 3 major factors as to what really is going to drive our earnings growth going forward. It's some level of organic growth, and we've mentioned the fact that it was a very modest macro environment recently, and
componenttext: And Frank, this is the other Frank. There are 3 major factors as to what really is going to drive our earnings growth going forward. It's some level of organic growth, and we've mentioned the fact that it was a very modest macro environment recently, and that may continue. But to the extent we have some level of organic growth similar to what we've seen, hopefully a little bit better as Michael mentioned, GDP or at least, the cost rationalization that we've just referred to as well as the accretive deployment, whether that be M&A or share purchase, a combination of those, some combination of those gives us confidence that we'll continue to grow earnings at a reasonable level.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. That's -- that is helpful. I think you were referring to something like a $60 million incremental additional costs to -- for growth spending in the quarter, something of that order of magnitude. How long do you anticipate that incrementally hig
componenttext: All right. That's -- that is helpful. I think you were referring to something like a $60 million incremental additional costs to -- for growth spending in the quarter, something of that order of magnitude. How long do you anticipate that incrementally higher gross spending to occur? And at what point do you anticipate realizing a return on that added investment?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Frank, I don't think I'd be plugging $60 million into your model. So these spending initiatives are directly tied to product launches. So as you know, our product at Home Depot was first put out, the Glidden Diamond. It was fully set in the Fourth
componenttext: Yes. So Frank, I don't think I'd be plugging $60 million into your model. So these spending initiatives are directly tied to product launches. So as you know, our product at Home Depot was first put out, the Glidden Diamond. It was fully set in the Fourth of July weekend. So we're certainly behind that product. It has started out very well. The Menards product as well, the superpremium price point, there was also set. That's our PITTSBURGH PAINTS Paramount. So those spendings are directly tied to the new product launches. So you won't have that in the fourth quarter. We're working with our partners on the launches for 2017, and we'll be back to you if we expect to see those kind of spending going forward. But we are going to continue to invest in growth-related initiatives.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is -- should we factor something like $0.20 incremental benefit by the options of that -- of those added costs, something of that order of magnitude?
componenttext: Is -- should we factor something like $0.20 incremental benefit by the options of that -- of those added costs, something of that order of magnitude?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, Frank, that's on a full year basis, and we only have this cost in Q3. So I think if you're analyzing -- annualizing that, as Michael said, this is only one quarter's worth, which was probably $0.04.
componenttext: Well, again, Frank, that's on a full year basis, and we only have this cost in Q3. So I think if you're analyzing -- annualizing that, as Michael said, this is only one quarter's worth, which was probably $0.04.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Christopher Parkinson with Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: The next question comes from Christopher Parkinson with Crdit Suisse.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perfect. Just digging down a little more on what you're seeing in the global auto OEM businesses. Can you just comment on your expectations for geographic growth mix between Mexico and the U.S. as well as any regional trends intra-Europe that you've seen?
componenttext: Perfect. Just digging down a little more on what you're seeing in the global auto OEM businesses. Can you just comment on your expectations for geographic growth mix between Mexico and the U.S. as well as any regional trends intra-Europe that you've seen? And then also just given some uncertainty regarding the Chinese auto market reaction to any changes in consumer incentives, can you just quickly comment on what you're seeing in small vehicle versus small CVs and your relative exposures there?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Chris, let's start with Mexico. As you know, there are a number of new automotive plants in Mexico that will be coming up in the next -- well, starting now through 2018. And those plants will obviously drive higher growth rate in Mexico than histo
componenttext: Yes. So Chris, let's start with Mexico. As you know, there are a number of new automotive plants in Mexico that will be coming up in the next -- well, starting now through 2018. And those plants will obviously drive higher growth rate in Mexico than historically. That would -- that may or may not necessarily detract from the U.S., but the overall U.S. market, we expect to be relatively flat next year. We're watching closely the incentives that the automotive manufacturers are putting out there. And I think we'll just continue to watch that closely. Europe, at 14 million builds, still has room to run. Southern Europe continues to perform very well. So if you look at what's going on in Spain, it was up double digits. Italy was up double digits. Germany was still up 5%. So -- and we're starting to see a little life in France in the automotive side, unfortunately not in the architectural side, but the automotive side. So that's all good. So I would think that, that's going to be a positive number next year in Europe. And then back to your question about China, first of all, China is -- has the -- a reduced tax out there through the end of 2016. There's no indication on whether or not they're going to make a change on that. I do believe, from a personal perspective, that China wants their automotive business to be a champion. They are just now starting to export a very small amount of cars out of China. We would expect them to continue to support them. So I am not looking for a material change in the China automotive growth rate. In fact, I would say it's going to grow again next year. And I won't be surprised if it has many, many years to run because if you look at the number of cars per person in China, it's still very, very low. And it is a big status symbol when you buy a car in China. So that's going to continue.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perfect, and just a very quick follow-up. You mentioned $75 million in sales at below-average segment margins in industrial. So can you very quickly comment about the cadence of your efforts pertaining to these businesses getting up towards your targets a
componenttext: Perfect, and just a very quick follow-up. You mentioned $75 million in sales at below-average segment margins in industrial. So can you very quickly comment about the cadence of your efforts pertaining to these businesses getting up towards your targets as well as any broad -- keyword broad comments you have on how we should think about the M&A pipeline going forward in the context of margins?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris, this is Vince. As is typical, when we acquire, especially a smaller bolt-on type transactions, they're not at our segment margin levels, whether it be performance or Industrial Coatings segments. It typically takes us a minimum of 1 year to start t
componenttext: Chris, this is Vince. As is typical, when we acquire, especially a smaller bolt-on type transactions, they're not at our segment margin levels, whether it be performance or Industrial Coatings segments. It typically takes us a minimum of 1 year to start to extract the full synergies from those transactions. And so that's a normal cadence we would see on a traditional transaction. With respect to the acquisition pipeline, I think Michael mentioned it earlier. We do have a very active pipeline in the industry. I think Michael said a quarter ago, one of the most active we've seen, which is, I think, helpful for us as we look into 2000 -- late 2016 and early 2017 for potential consummation.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Ghansham Panjabi with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: The next question comes from Ghansham Panjabi with Robert W. Baird.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, first off, on auto refinish and the decline in 3Q volumes in Europe, Michael, do you sort of view this as an inventory correction in the supply chain? And did you see it in any particular subregion within Europe?
componenttext: Yes, first off, on auto refinish and the decline in 3Q volumes in Europe, Michael, do you sort of view this as an inventory correction in the supply chain? And did you see it in any particular subregion within Europe?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ghansham, I think that, overall, by and large, Southern Europe is outperforming Northern Europe. Obviously, Russia remains weak. Eastern Europe is not as strong as we'd like to see. But overall, I think, as I said earlier on the call, that the -- this 14
componenttext: Ghansham, I think that, overall, by and large, Southern Europe is outperforming Northern Europe. Obviously, Russia remains weak. Eastern Europe is not as strong as we'd like to see. But overall, I think, as I said earlier on the call, that the -- this 14 million build rate that they're at can grow significantly higher. If you think about the number of people in Europe versus the U.S., there's no reason why it can't climb up to a substantially higher number. And they have historically been at a higher number if you go back to the 2006 and '07 time frame.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ghansham, just one other point on refinish and I'll relate it back to that China discussion that we just had. We had -- we saw a very nice growth mid- to upper digits on refinish in Asia, primarily China. And that goes back to the dynamic of the carpa
componenttext: And Ghansham, just one other point on refinish and I'll relate it back to that China discussion that we just had. We had -- we saw a very nice growth mid- to upper digits on refinish in Asia, primarily China. And that goes back to the dynamic of the carpark being relatively low per capita that Michael referred to and that bodes very well for the future growth of refinish in China as that carpark continues to grow. So we're seeing nice uptick there despite some of the slight softness we saw over in the European market.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And just as a follow-up on the protective coatings. I know marine's been quite weak across the board, particularly in Asia, but you called out some volume improvement in North America. Can you just sort of expand on that?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And just as a follow-up on the protective coatings. I know marine's been quite weak across the board, particularly in Asia, but you called out some volume improvement in North America. Can you just sort of expand on that?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. The volume improvement is all in the protective area. And what's interesting is that we've seen a moderation in the decline now in oil and gas. We haven't seen any significant pickup. But I think they've done a significant amount of capital project
componenttext: Sure. The volume improvement is all in the protective area. And what's interesting is that we've seen a moderation in the decline now in oil and gas. We haven't seen any significant pickup. But I think they've done a significant amount of capital project cutting. And so I think over the next couple of quarters, that's going to moderate and then start to turn up. So on the protective side, quite good. We're also seeing people doing the dry-docking. They're going to try to make the ships last a little longer, so dry-docking is up.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I could add, Ghansham, this is Vince. We had, based on our estimates, above-market growth in the U.S. and Canada in protective. This is a business 2 years ago, we started talking about trying to build additional growth actions on. And I think you'r
componenttext: And if I could add, Ghansham, this is Vince. We had, based on our estimates, above-market growth in the U.S. and Canada in protective. This is a business 2 years ago, we started talking about trying to build additional growth actions on. And I think you're seeing today some of those benefits from those growth actions.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Arun Viswanathan with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question comes from Arun Viswanathan with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Just had a question, I guess, on volume growth. You did 1.5%, 1.6% here in Q3 on a relatively, I guess, easy comp of minus 0.7% last year. You're coming up on a tougher comp here in Q4. So what's your expectation on volume growth in Q4?
componenttext: Right. Just had a question, I guess, on volume growth. You did 1.5%, 1.6% here in Q3 on a relatively, I guess, easy comp of minus 0.7% last year. You're coming up on a tougher comp here in Q4. So what's your expectation on volume growth in Q4?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Arun, I think the volume growth has continued to remain muted. We're not seeing any changes in the environment out there. As I mentioned on my pre -- or my remarks in the beginning, we've already seen most of our October order book. Fourth quarter i
componenttext: Well, Arun, I think the volume growth has continued to remain muted. We're not seeing any changes in the environment out there. As I mentioned on my pre -- or my remarks in the beginning, we've already seen most of our October order book. Fourth quarter is typically a seasonally weaker quarter. And so I would tell you it's just going to be more of the same that we saw in the third quarter and earlier this year.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's fair. And then -- and just, I guess, looking out into 2017, I remember last year at this point, you guys were thinking that maybe you could push volume growth up into the low to mid-single digits for '16. Is there any possibility that we could get
componenttext: That's fair. And then -- and just, I guess, looking out into 2017, I remember last year at this point, you guys were thinking that maybe you could push volume growth up into the low to mid-single digits for '16. Is there any possibility that we could get there in '17 despite the market? Or is it still going to be dependent on your individual end markets?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, aspirationally, we try to grow at GDP or GDP plus. We haven't done that this year, which is disappointing to us, Arun. But as we look at next year, we're going to need certainly good performance execution-wise internally. But we also need a l
componenttext: Well, again, aspirationally, we try to grow at GDP or GDP plus. We haven't done that this year, which is disappointing to us, Arun. But as we look at next year, we're going to need certainly good performance execution-wise internally. But we also need a little bit of growth uptick in the different verticals we play in. So I think we're still aspirationally striving to get to what you're talking about, and we'll have to see how the environment plays out.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just as a last quick follow-up, the OEM performance in the Americas was slightly, you've characterized, as below market. What would you say led to that? And is that unusual? Or do you see it kind of a change in that going forward?
componenttext: And just as a last quick follow-up, the OEM performance in the Americas was slightly, you've characterized, as below market. What would you say led to that? And is that unusual? Or do you see it kind of a change in that going forward?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Arun. I think we covered this in the prior 2 conference calls. At that time, if you go into 2016, we had opportunities to try to take business in certain parts of the world versus others. We preferentially wanted to gain share in Asia. And obviously,
componenttext: No, Arun. I think we covered this in the prior 2 conference calls. At that time, if you go into 2016, we had opportunities to try to take business in certain parts of the world versus others. We preferentially wanted to gain share in Asia. And obviously, we've gained share at a significantly higher rate than the rest of the industry for the 2013, 2014, 2015. And so the customers were getting uncomfortable given our growth rate. So we preferentially gave up share in the U.S., where we saw that growth rate slowing and continue to grow in Asia. And so overall, despite the decline in U.S., we are performing at market. And then we expect to be outperforming the markets starting first quarter of next year.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Jeff Zekauskas with JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question comes from Jeff Zekauskas with JPMorgan.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: When I look at your industrial business, your revenues were basically flat from the second to the third quarter, but your operating profits were down $43 million, and your margin contracted about 300 basis points. So what exactly is going on there? Is it
componenttext: When I look at your industrial business, your revenues were basically flat from the second to the third quarter, but your operating profits were down $43 million, and your margin contracted about 300 basis points. So what exactly is going on there? Is it lower prices? Is it mix? This degree of margin change doesn't seem to be accounted for by volume.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, if you go sequentially from 2Q to 3Q, we have a dramatically different business mix by industrial segment such as automotive versus general industrial. As you know, a lot of the auto companies take significant outages in July or August depending whe
componenttext: Jeff, if you go sequentially from 2Q to 3Q, we have a dramatically different business mix by industrial segment such as automotive versus general industrial. As you know, a lot of the auto companies take significant outages in July or August depending whether it's U.S. or Europe, as opposed to Q2 where they're running at peak production. So the business mix differs tremendously. And we see a similar margin erosion each year sequentially 2Q to 3Q in that particular segment.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think last year, the margin deterioration sequentially was about 60 basis points, and that was on much lower sequential sales. Did it turn out that -- were there any management compensation changes, either for the third quarter or the fourth quarter pro
componenttext: I think last year, the margin deterioration sequentially was about 60 basis points, and that was on much lower sequential sales. Did it turn out that -- were there any management compensation changes, either for the third quarter or the fourth quarter prospectively? Because you're probably not on the plan that you originally were guiding toward.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, this is Vince again. We readjust our management compensation each quarter based on our quarterly and full year outlook as well as stock-based comp is impacted by the stock price itself. There were no significant -- in Q3, excuse me, there were no si
componenttext: Jeff, this is Vince again. We readjust our management compensation each quarter based on our quarterly and full year outlook as well as stock-based comp is impacted by the stock price itself. There were no significant -- in Q3, excuse me, there were no significant, noteworthy changes on those 2 line items. So that -- hopefully that answers your question, if I addressed it properly.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Does it benefit you in Q4? Is there a meaningful change? Or there isn't?
componenttext: Does it benefit you in Q4? Is there a meaningful change? Or there isn't?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, unfortunately, the stock price is down. The stock price fell along with our preannouncement. So that'll affect stock-based compensation. We'll evaluate the businesses as we do every year, at the end of the year on the various metrics that we have fo
componenttext: Well, unfortunately, the stock price is down. The stock price fell along with our preannouncement. So that'll affect stock-based compensation. We'll evaluate the businesses as we do every year, at the end of the year on the various metrics that we have for each of them.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from David Begleiter with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: The next question comes from David Begleiter with Deutsche Bank.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, looking at M&A and consolidation coatings, is there potential for large-scale M&A still left in the coatings industry globally?
componenttext: Michael, looking at M&A and consolidation coatings, is there potential for large-scale M&A still left in the coatings industry globally?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, definitely. I think you saw that with the fact that Sherwin made their announcement earlier this year. There are still a number of fair-sized acquisition opportunities out there. I don't want you to walk away thinking that there's anything dif
componenttext: Yes, David, definitely. I think you saw that with the fact that Sherwin made their announcement earlier this year. There are still a number of fair-sized acquisition opportunities out there. I don't want you to walk away thinking that there's anything different. I think if you parse the global data really finely, you'll see that there's been about 20 companies that have added or been listed at over $0.5 billion in the past 3 or 4 years. So there's continued global growth in coatings companies. And of course, you know the top 10 are out there, too. So there's still more opportunity. So I would just encourage you to be patient.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just on a point in Q4, Michael, the $650 million of cash deployment, is that likely to be more buybacks or more M&A?
componenttext: And just on a point in Q4, Michael, the $650 million of cash deployment, is that likely to be more buybacks or more M&A?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, this is Frank. As we've always said, our preference would be to do accretive acquisitions, but in any quarter where there would not necessarily be an acquisition closed or completed, we would still be sure to reach our goals for cash deployment. So
componenttext: David, this is Frank. As we've always said, our preference would be to do accretive acquisitions, but in any quarter where there would not necessarily be an acquisition closed or completed, we would still be sure to reach our goals for cash deployment. So I think it's premature to say exactly what the mix will be for Q4. But we are committed to reach the top end of our previous guidance of $2 billion to $2.5 billion, so at least $650 million is a good number, whether it be share repurchase or acquisition.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Kevin McCarthy with Vertical Research Partners.
componenttext: The next question comes from Kevin McCarthy with Vertical Research Partners.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you would comment on how you see your capital expenditures trending through 2017 in light of your updated macro outlook and also recognizing the Glass business as you're moving out of the portfolio.
componenttext: I was wondering if you would comment on how you see your capital expenditures trending through 2017 in light of your updated macro outlook and also recognizing the Glass business as you're moving out of the portfolio.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Kevin, this is Frank. We have said that in the recent past that our capital expenditures as a percent of revenue would be in the 3% to 3.5% range. With the Glass business -- flat glass business coming out and European fiber glass coming out, those were
componenttext: So Kevin, this is Frank. We have said that in the recent past that our capital expenditures as a percent of revenue would be in the 3% to 3.5% range. With the Glass business -- flat glass business coming out and European fiber glass coming out, those were typically more capital-intensive businesses, albeit on a periodic basis. But this gives us confidence that the trend going forward will be more in the circa 3% range of revenue. And along with looking at the macro environment that you referred to, we're being very disciplined in terms of deploying the actual individual projects, whether they be for cost savings, capacity growth, whatever. So gating the CapEx in a very, very careful way, so we do not get ahead of the market. So you might interpret that by meeting the fact that our previous outlook in terms of percent of revenue for CapEx in 2016, we're hoping come in at the low end of that percentage range and be very efficient how we deploy that kind of just-in-time basis.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then second question if I may. Wanted to clarify what might be going on with regard to your corporate expense. There was a fairly large sequential drop. Last year, when that happened, I think variable comp was part of that. I'm wondering if you
componenttext: Okay. And then second question if I may. Wanted to clarify what might be going on with regard to your corporate expense. There was a fairly large sequential drop. Last year, when that happened, I think variable comp was part of that. I'm wondering if you can elaborate on what happened here in the quarter you just reported and what the outlook might be for 4Q.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's probably a little more normalized this quarter than it was last year in Q3. You were right in saying that it was unusually low last year, and some of that was driven by the share price Q3 last year. We do the measurement on a stock-based compensation
componenttext: It's probably a little more normalized this quarter than it was last year in Q3. You were right in saying that it was unusually low last year, and some of that was driven by the share price Q3 last year. We do the measurement on a stock-based compensation, including the share price at the end of the quarter. So we had an uptick in that stock-based compensation expense, Q3 versus Q3. And of course, when we look out to Q4, that will depend upon how that particular factor plays out. But the remainder of the corporate expense bucket going forward, that would be, obviously, one area along with all other areas of cost that we'll be assessing as we go forward in terms of our rationalization program. So the goal is to structurally be as efficient as we possibly can. And then the stock-based compensation and other performance-based compensation will be based upon the share price as well as our financial results.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Don Carson with SIG.
componenttext: The next question comes from Don Carson with SIG.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on architectural coatings, both year performance and the overall market. In Q3, you had some easy year-ago comps. So just wondering if sort of -- if you look at volumes that went out the door, gallons to customers, was that actually up year-ove
componenttext: A question on architectural coatings, both year performance and the overall market. In Q3, you had some easy year-ago comps. So just wondering if sort of -- if you look at volumes that went out the door, gallons to customers, was that actually up year-over-year? Or what impacted this inventory destocking by customer have on the year-over-year comparisons? And then in your outlook, you talk about architectural coatings in the U.S. and Canada. That end use demand remains modest. Coming into the year, everybody thought there'd be a demand snapback because of tough weather comps last year. Just wonder what your latest assessment of the overall U.S. architectural market is.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, let -- Don, this is Mike. Let's just start with the assumption. We -- all year, we've been saying that it would be in the 2% to 4% range. So I think our assessment has been relatively accurate. And so this past quarter, overall, we were up low singl
componenttext: Okay, let -- Don, this is Mike. Let's just start with the assumption. We -- all year, we've been saying that it would be in the 2% to 4% range. So I think our assessment has been relatively accurate. And so this past quarter, overall, we were up low single digits. And that was over obviously a quarter, prior year that was a little bit weaker than we expected. We did have some bright spots. Certainly, the home centers did very well from that standpoint. So we had -- all of our retail partners had a good quarter from that standpoint as far as paint sales were. Our trade business was up also. So our company-owned stores continue to perform better. So we're -- we think we're closing the gap in that regard. And we're seeing the modest improvement in Canada as well. So I would tell you that the industry has been about where we're expecting in that 2% to 4% range. And we expect to see next year in a similar-type fashion.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Ivan Marcuse with KeyBanc.
componenttext: The next question comes from Ivan Marcuse with KeyBanc.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Real quick in the refinish, and if you commented on this, I apologize. But in Europe it was -- it contracted a little bit, tends to be pretty historically pretty consistent business. Was there any sort of prebuying that maybe benefited the second quarter
componenttext: Real quick in the refinish, and if you commented on this, I apologize. But in Europe it was -- it contracted a little bit, tends to be pretty historically pretty consistent business. Was there any sort of prebuying that maybe benefited the second quarter and hurt you in the third quarter? Or is there something else going on there?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. For refinish in Europe, the only thing that we really noticed was that the claim -- the insurance companies in the U.K. have been getting tighter and tighter on claim management. Other than that, I would say there was nothing significant. Certainly, o
componenttext: No. For refinish in Europe, the only thing that we really noticed was that the claim -- the insurance companies in the U.K. have been getting tighter and tighter on claim management. Other than that, I would say there was nothing significant. Certainly, our waterborne products continue to take share in -- over there. And we did have a nice win that we'll be talking about, I'm sure, in the first quarter call when it starts to add to the bottom line.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in terms of cash flow, a couple part question, I guess. What was your cash flow from operations for the first 9 months? And then when you look out in 2017, where do you expect your environmental -- how much lower do you expect your environm
componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of cash flow, a couple part question, I guess. What was your cash flow from operations for the first 9 months? And then when you look out in 2017, where do you expect your environmental -- how much lower do you expect your environmental spending and pension spending outflow when you look out to 2017?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ivan, I'll take the cash flow question. I think Frank is going to address the other 2. We're going to put out our 10-Q in the next few days. The cash flow is a little bit murky simply because we have a significant amount of pension-related specials. We ha
componenttext: Ivan, I'll take the cash flow question. I think Frank is going to address the other 2. We're going to put out our 10-Q in the next few days. The cash flow is a little bit murky simply because we have a significant amount of pension-related specials. We have some asbestos payments that are reflected as liability reductions. So the numbers, you'll need to see the pieces, which will be very well articulated in the Q. We're up about -- on an apples-to-apples basis, excluding some of the specials, we're up just below 10% year-over-year on a cash flow basis, but you'll need to see the specials to fully understand that. Frank, I think you...

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, on the environmental spending, Ivan, so we are planning to spend about half this year of what we spent in total environmental cash versus last year. Last year, we spent about $100 million, about half that this year. Obviously, the environmental spend
componenttext: Yes, on the environmental spending, Ivan, so we are planning to spend about half this year of what we spent in total environmental cash versus last year. Last year, we spent about $100 million, about half that this year. Obviously, the environmental spending can -- has some level of unpredictability based upon how the parcels are remediated and any additional work that we find. And this is an ongoing journey that's been going on for a few decades. But generally, we think that the run rate of cash spending in environmental this year is more representative to what we would see going forward. And hopefully, over time, it will continue to modestly diminish. In terms of pension spending, we did say that we would have about $175 million of top up of some of the plans that resulted from the annuitizations we did on both the U.S. and Canadian side. We put about $50 million of that into the plans in Q3. We've got another $125 million to do between Q4 and 2017. So that will occur over to that period of time. Aside from that, there's some very modest, I'll say, high single, low double-digit millions of dollars that we put toward the international plans on an annual basis.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then last question in terms of working capital. With raw materials, I guess, probably turning higher for [indiscernible] into 2017. Are you still going to be able to continue to work this 110 -- 100 basis point type of improvement goal?
componenttext: Okay, and then last question in terms of working capital. With raw materials, I guess, probably turning higher for [indiscernible] into 2017. Are you still going to be able to continue to work this 110 -- 100 basis point type of improvement goal?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say -- this is Frank again. I would say that working capital has been a very -- has been real bright spot, particularly in Q3, where all 3 elements of working capital, receivables, payables and inventory, have improved in days. In fact, we took mi
componenttext: I would say -- this is Frank again. I would say that working capital has been a very -- has been real bright spot, particularly in Q3, where all 3 elements of working capital, receivables, payables and inventory, have improved in days. In fact, we took mid-single-digit days out of inventory in Q3. We need to continue to make some progress because we still think there is a gap to our peers in that respect. That will come from a combination of more rigorous S&OP process, but also complexity reduction. And we do continue to think that there will be additional, we'll call it, 100 basis points or so on an annual basis of improvement in working capital, but pleased with the progress so far. More work to do.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Laurence Alexander with Jefferies.
componenttext: The next question comes from Laurence Alexander with Jefferies.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Dan Rizzo on for Laurence. You guys mentioned before that sometimes it takes a year to get the synergistic gains because of lower margins of the bolt-ons you guys are doing. I was just wondering in light of what M&A activity -- increased M&A activ
componenttext: This is Dan Rizzo on for Laurence. You guys mentioned before that sometimes it takes a year to get the synergistic gains because of lower margins of the bolt-ons you guys are doing. I was just wondering in light of what M&A activity -- increased M&A activity and the higher valuations that we're seeing if that's getting harder and harder to do. And if it's taking longer now as we move, I mean, as -- and looking to take longer as we look forward.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, this is Michael. There's been no change. We're very experienced in acquisitions. We've done more than 50 acquisitions in the past 10 years. We have a very dynamic playbook that we consistently apply. And so we expect fully to any buy that we buy that
componenttext: Dan, this is Michael. There's been no change. We're very experienced in acquisitions. We've done more than 50 acquisitions in the past 10 years. We have a very dynamic playbook that we consistently apply. And so we expect fully to any buy that we buy that's below our system average to get them up to our system average in a relatively simple period of time. I mean, we get the raw materials quickly. We get to move on to the best practices next. Then we do the back office and then we bring in our new products, PPG products. So we expect to be there. We're not at all concerned. I mean, we just did MetoKote. We've already picked up $1 million of those synergies in the first 90 days. So we're going to be okay in that area.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then you also indicated on another there question that there are a lot of -- there are still a number larger acquisitions out there in the few hundred million dollar range. I was just wondering if expectations again are too high just given some of the
componenttext: And then you also indicated on another there question that there are a lot of -- there are still a number larger acquisitions out there in the few hundred million dollar range. I was just wondering if expectations again are too high just given some of the larger purchases we've seen and what people are expecting going forward that -- so that while they're there, it's just not even -- it's a nonstarter in terms of what people are expecting at that level.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's a fair question. And I would tell you that everybody starts with their own idea about what a fair price is. I would tell you that we're not paying 15x. We're going to remain disciplined. But I don't expect that the current elevation of
componenttext: Well, I think it's a fair question. And I would tell you that everybody starts with their own idea about what a fair price is. I would tell you that we're not paying 15x. We're going to remain disciplined. But I don't expect that the current elevation of a couple of specific, unique transactions drive the entire market. So we didn't pay anywhere near that for MetoKote. And we have others that we're working on right now that aren't in that stratosphere. Certainly, we are going to have to react to the marketplace. I don't know whether some of our competitors, they're thinking that 0-rate interest rate environment is going to be here forever. But we certainly recognize that there are different expectations when you do an acquisition.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just following up very quickly on Michael's comment around discipline, that's a very important point. At the end of the day, we benchmark against the return that we get by returning cash to shareholders and what we can get from that on risk-adjusted b
componenttext: And just following up very quickly on Michael's comment around discipline, that's a very important point. At the end of the day, we benchmark against the return that we get by returning cash to shareholders and what we can get from that on risk-adjusted basis. If we can have an accretive acquisition that returns in excess of our weighted average cost of capital, that's really the benchmark. That's not necessarily comparing to any other recent deal. And that includes any synergies that we can get either on the revenue or cost side.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Dmitry Silversteyn with Longbow Research.
componenttext: The next question comes from Dmitry Silversteyn with Longbow Research.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question. Looking at the margins of both performance and Industrial Coatings businesses, they were down year-over-year, I think, for the first time since the fourth quarter of 2014. Can you talk about -- you talked about raw materials still b
componenttext: Just a quick question. Looking at the margins of both performance and Industrial Coatings businesses, they were down year-over-year, I think, for the first time since the fourth quarter of 2014. Can you talk about -- you talked about raw materials still being a little bit of a benefit. I understand you didn't get the incremental margin on the volume growth that you're going to -- that you were expecting. But still trying to understand why the margins calmed down on year-over-year basis.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dmitry, Vince. We'll take them one at a time. I think when you look at the Performance Coatings business, again, we did have additional growth-related spending that crimped our margins this quarter in that particular segment. Certainly, the margin growth
componenttext: Dmitry, Vince. We'll take them one at a time. I think when you look at the Performance Coatings business, again, we did have additional growth-related spending that crimped our margins this quarter in that particular segment. Certainly, the margin growth was contracting, as you noted, due to the diminishing benefit of raw materials. But $15 million of additional growth-related spending was impactful in that particular segment. If you flip to the industrial segment, as Michael alluded to earlier, we did see -- we are working with our customers in that segment on our selling prices to them, and that's the one factor I would point to in that particular segment. In both these segments, there's always puts and takes outside of those particular items, but those would be the 2 key items.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Vince. That's helpful. Question on sort of the general industrial business, which was very strong in this quarter, I think you're up about 6%, including the specialty materials. Was -- so my question is, was it mostly specialty materials and what yo
componenttext: Okay, Vince. That's helpful. Question on sort of the general industrial business, which was very strong in this quarter, I think you're up about 6%, including the specialty materials. Was -- so my question is, was it mostly specialty materials and what you have left over from optics and sealants that were up? Or did your general industrial business, in terms of coatings, really did see this level of growth? And if it's the latter, was there any particular markets or geographies where you've done this much better than the market?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, actually, Dmitry, our specialty coatings materials was actually the weakest of the 4 that were in there. Automotive had a very good quarter as we talked about. And our industrial team had a very good quarter. I mean, when you look at it, our automoti
componenttext: Yes, actually, Dmitry, our specialty coatings materials was actually the weakest of the 4 that were in there. Automotive had a very good quarter as we talked about. And our industrial team had a very good quarter. I mean, when you look at it, our automotive parts and accessories was up high single digits. Our coil business was up high single digits. Wood was up. Transportation coatings were up. Heavy-duty equipment was up for the first time in a long time. I mean, I'd have to guess, but at least 2 years. So our packaging business continued their year-over-year growth. I mean, we are in the beginning of a secular growth rate for this, so they were up high single digits, the move to BPA-NI. So really, when you look at it, the specialty coatings materials had a -- they were the weakest of the 4. So it was everybody contributing, though.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The heavy-duty equipment was -- is particularly noteworthy as you pointed out. I mean, it's been a while since we saw strength in that business. And there are certainly nothing from the Caterpillars and the other equipment suppliers of the world that woul
componenttext: The heavy-duty equipment was -- is particularly noteworthy as you pointed out. I mean, it's been a while since we saw strength in that business. And there are certainly nothing from the Caterpillars and the other equipment suppliers of the world that would lead us to believe that this is a recovering market. So was this share gain? Was this kind of a onetime? I mean, what's behind this? Can we look forward to this growth or at least nondecline in this troubled industry continuing for you?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it was definitely share growth in that industry. We have worked hard to increase our share in that area. The customers are very comfortable with our ability to deliver more productivity in their shops. That's what they're looking for. And we've been
componenttext: Yes, it was definitely share growth in that industry. We have worked hard to increase our share in that area. The customers are very comfortable with our ability to deliver more productivity in their shops. That's what they're looking for. And we've been able to deliver that productivity through value-added products, and that's what's driving it. So the industry itself, as you know, you can read the papers, continue to be quite weak, but we're very pleased with our team's performance.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Vincent Andrews with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: The next question comes from Vincent Andrews with Morgan Stanley.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Matt Gingrich on for Vincent. I was hoping that you could clarify the progress on your current and ongoing cost programs as well as the Comex cost synergy targets.
componenttext: This is Matt Gingrich on for Vincent. I was hoping that you could clarify the progress on your current and ongoing cost programs as well as the Comex cost synergy targets.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Vince. The Comex cost synergy targets, we've completed that fully by the end of last year actually. We do have some sales synergy targets for Comex that we're -- are primarily related to PPG products going into Mexico as well as Central Ameri
componenttext: Yes, this is Vince. The Comex cost synergy targets, we've completed that fully by the end of last year actually. We do have some sales synergy targets for Comex that we're -- are primarily related to PPG products going into Mexico as well as Central America. Those are on track. They're slightly above track. The other restructuring program that we announced last year, again, diminishing benefits as we approach the fourth quarter, so very modest benefits in the fourth quarter and will be fully captured at that point.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Nils Wallin with CLSA.
componenttext: The next question comes from Nils Wallin with CLSA.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. When you talk about the M&A pipeline, a lot of opportunities in there. Are you -- could you just help us understand that a little bit better? Is that because there are more -- there are fewer folks competing with you, there's more product -- more ass
componenttext: Yes. When you talk about the M&A pipeline, a lot of opportunities in there. Are you -- could you just help us understand that a little bit better? Is that because there are more -- there are fewer folks competing with you, there's more product -- more assets coming to market or, in general, companies that you've been looking at over the last couple of years are getting close to the finish line?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think, Nils, the way I would think about it is there are several properties that are out there that are coming to the market because they see the prices that are out there. And so that makes more people think about whether or not this is the time to
componenttext: No, I think, Nils, the way I would think about it is there are several properties that are out there that are coming to the market because they see the prices that are out there. And so that makes more people think about whether or not this is the time to get out some of their investments. I would also tell you that we have historically worked with a number of these family-owned companies for many, many years. And it takes a long time sometimes to build that relationship to get them to the point where they feel comfortable ready to pull the trigger, whether it's generational change, whether it's been a dynamic, where they're looking to reduce their focus on the coatings business or whatever the dynamic might be. So we're going to continue to work with our potential acquisitions, whether it's a family-owned company or some of these private equity owned ones. And so I think their -- the pipeline looks solid.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just on Europe, I mean, you've long said that you get some volume growth in Europe, you get very, very attractive incremental margins. When you have this sort of flat volume growth environment, does that mean you have 0 incremental margins? Or
componenttext: Great. And just on Europe, I mean, you've long said that you get some volume growth in Europe, you get very, very attractive incremental margins. When you have this sort of flat volume growth environment, does that mean you have 0 incremental margins? Or that it might actually be decremental?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: In general, Nils, what you said is correct. I mean, no growth that -- it doesn't matter what your margins are if you're not growing. But we do have some business mix differences in Europe. So we could have pluses or minuses just around business mix. But g
componenttext: In general, Nils, what you said is correct. I mean, no growth that -- it doesn't matter what your margins are if you're not growing. But we do have some business mix differences in Europe. So we could have pluses or minuses just around business mix. But generally, what you said is accurate.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think -- this is Frank. Just to follow up quickly, the -- you have decremental margins at the profit contribution line, but that's another reason why we're looking at our total cost structure, so we can minimize any downside if the volume becomes mu
componenttext: And I think -- this is Frank. Just to follow up quickly, the -- you have decremental margins at the profit contribution line, but that's another reason why we're looking at our total cost structure, so we can minimize any downside if the volume becomes muted in the near future. So -- and the team over there has done a very good job thus far. But there's some additional opportunities that we're going to be looking at in conjunction with this next set of initiatives we're talking about.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Mike Harrison with Seaport Global Securities.
componenttext: The next question comes from Mike Harrison with Seaport Global Securities.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, you mentioned that your larger customers tend to get some of the more attractive pricing, and the smaller customers would get a better pricing from your standpoint. Was wondering if your comment on heavy equipment manufacturers being stronger in
componenttext: Michael, you mentioned that your larger customers tend to get some of the more attractive pricing, and the smaller customers would get a better pricing from your standpoint. Was wondering if your comment on heavy equipment manufacturers being stronger in the quarter, could that be another component of negative mix affecting the margin performance of the Industrial Coatings segment?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say that's a very, very small factor. I mean, when you think about heavy-duty equipment has reduced its size and scope overall of our Industrial Coatings because of their decline. So it has no real material impact.
componenttext: I would say that's a very, very small factor. I mean, when you think about heavy-duty equipment has reduced its size and scope overall of our Industrial Coatings because of their decline. So it has no real material impact.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then just looking at the decline of the Mexican peso and the impact on the Comex business, are all of the cost that you incur in that business peso denominated? Or are you seeing some transactional impact because you're paying dollars for s
componenttext: All right. And then just looking at the decline of the Mexican peso and the impact on the Comex business, are all of the cost that you incur in that business peso denominated? Or are you seeing some transactional impact because you're paying dollars for some of your raw materials or other costs?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Frank. Most of the costs are peso denominated. There is a little bit of transaction exposure from buying some materials from outside of Mexico, but we do have the ability to hedge a portion of that. We don't get into details as to how much we do.
componenttext: This is Frank. Most of the costs are peso denominated. There is a little bit of transaction exposure from buying some materials from outside of Mexico, but we do have the ability to hedge a portion of that. We don't get into details as to how much we do. But the limited transactional exposure there is, we do have the ability to mitigate that. Plus there is also pricing opportunity when you see these kinds of movements on currency. So that's also another mitigating factor, which is the reason that business continues to perform very, very well on both the top line and bottom line.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Mike, let me just add to that. So from the Comex perspective, they continue to outpace our original target, which is 2x GDP. We've opened up 67 new stores in the quarter. We're at 168 new stores through the first 3 months. So we're going to exceed our
componenttext: So Mike, let me just add to that. So from the Comex perspective, they continue to outpace our original target, which is 2x GDP. We've opened up 67 new stores in the quarter. We're at 168 new stores through the first 3 months. So we're going to exceed our target. So we're getting close to 4,200 stores in Mexico. So we're going to have probably 190 stores. We also opened up new stores, which we're not counting in Lowe's. So we have a store-in-store concept down there as well. So overall, even with the challenges to the peso, the PPG-Comex team has been doing a phenomenal job.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Duffy Fischer with Barclays.
componenttext: The next question comes from Duffy Fischer with Barclays.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Mike Leithead on for Duffy. Just one quick one following up on the restructuring actions you guys talked about today. I mean, is it too early to try to think about the size of the potential program there? I mean, as we start thinking about our 201
componenttext: This is Mike Leithead on for Duffy. Just one quick one following up on the restructuring actions you guys talked about today. I mean, is it too early to try to think about the size of the potential program there? I mean, as we start thinking about our 2017 forecast, should we bake in kind of a more than negligible amount of restructuring benefit? Or how should we think about that?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't want to go into specifics right now on the exact amount because we are still assessing all the potential actions we're looking at. What we can say is it's going to be broad-based and significant and will address all elements of the cost structure
componenttext: We don't want to go into specifics right now on the exact amount because we are still assessing all the potential actions we're looking at. What we can say is it's going to be broad-based and significant and will address all elements of the cost structure. And when we have the things kind of nailed down as part of our planning process, we'll update the market at the appropriate time.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: But Mike, as we've said in the past, generally, you take a couple of quarters to phase it in and then you start to get more benefits at the back half.
componenttext: But Mike, as we've said in the past, generally, you take a couple of quarters to phase it in and then you start to get more benefits at the back half.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough, and then if I could squeeze one more in on packaging. Can you talk about the kind of technology you guys have there and the transition to non-BPA coating and just kind of what inning we are there in that phase?
componenttext: Fair enough, and then if I could squeeze one more in on packaging. Can you talk about the kind of technology you guys have there and the transition to non-BPA coating and just kind of what inning we are there in that phase?

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we're on inning 3. So the BPA-nonintent coatings really started in France. They have factored their way over to the U.S. in some of the food applications. Now California, in fact, their regs and the way they're going to force people to talk about
componenttext: I think we're on inning 3. So the BPA-nonintent coatings really started in France. They have factored their way over to the U.S. in some of the food applications. Now California, in fact, their regs and the way they're going to force people to talk about it kicks -- kicked in actually October 18. So that will be more pressure in the marketplace to ship to the BPA-NI coatings. And of course, once that starts to happen, I always use tuna fish as an example. You pack cans in Thailand. Those cans show up in Europe. They show up in the U.S. And they're not going to run 2 and 3 different formulations for some of those tuna fish ones. So you're going to have certain markets following later just because of where they export to. So we're in the early innings, and we're really pleased with the acceptance of our new technology.

headline: PPG Industries, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I can add, this is one of businesses, again, where we're stacking year-on-year growth rates of very high levels. So we were up mid-single digits this quarter. That's on a very good comp last year. So that stacking effect is very helpful for us.
componenttext: If I can add, this is one of businesses, again, where we're stacking year-on-year growth rates of very high levels. So we were up mid-single digits this quarter. That's on a very good comp last year. So that stacking effect is very helpful for us.

componenttext: Well, we only have one that's falling and 7 are flat, and I talked about TiO2 being up. So it's -- right now, it's a relatively benign environment going into the fourth quarter. And we'll obviously have to wait to see how it looks with the first quarter. But that's how we stack them up.

componenttext: We do think -- Jim, we do have a benign global economy here, so the push for raw material inflation shouldn't -- there's not a demand-supported push for that.

componenttext: Jim, we put an 8-K in mid-September that provided by quarter the last several years of our EPS from continuing, excluding flat glass in mid, again let's call it mid-September. I think, for the fourth quarter, that was $1.16. The -- that fiber -- European fiber glass business will remain in continuing. It wasn't a sale of an entire business. So based on GAAP guidance, it remains in continuing.
